Yoko then smiled. "Good; then we should get along just fine." relaxing a little, she said. "I'm glad to see you are in better shape than before, you heal impressively fast for a human."

I looked down, solemn. "Mark told me I won't likely be human for long."

Yoko pulled my head up with her hand so to face me. "That is why you are here." softly, she said. "Welcome to Monster Manor."
1143111121.title: Tsuchigumo, spider girl.

11431111211.content:
"Monster Manor?" curious, I asked. "Is that what this house is called."

Yoko nodded. "Yes, this and other mansions in these caverns are homes for monsters who can not find a home for themselves where they are welcome for who they are." she explained. "There are four mansions in all, each with their own shack."

"There is the Earth mansion, where we are; the air mansion, deeper in; the water mansion, in an ocean cavern a few miles away; and the fire mansion, which is the deepest of all."

"Unless you become a stone golem, like Viva, I suggest you do not visit the fire mansion." serious, Yoko said. "You may not be able to take the heat."

"I'm still hoping to be able to return home." politely, I said. "I have a mother, friends..."

Yoko gave me a sad look. "I do not know what it feels like to transform into something else, I was born this way." softly, she said. "However, I can tell you from my own experience that you will not likely be welcomed back."

"Why?" hurt, I asked.

Yoko sighed. "Humans fear what they do not understand." calmly, she said. "I can small fear and you were terrified of me, at first." she grinned slightly. "I am pleased that you recovered from that quickly and treated me... 'normal'. Such humans are rare."

"Your mother may welcome you, Jon." touching my hand, Viva said. "But can she protect you against everyone else?" she looked down, solemn. "I was adopted by humans, they were kind to me but they were killed... protecting me from... those who were... not kind."

My heart went out to Viva. Having to lose not one set of parents but two had to be very hard for her to take at such a young age. I knelled down and hugged her as she silently sobbed against my shoulder until she was able to compose herself.

"There are a handful of humans out there who are genuinely kind, Jon." serious, Yoko said. "However, it is impossible to determine who is good and who is evil until it is almost too late."

I nodded in response and decided to change the subject. "Viva mentioned there were six others, counting Cecil." I said. "Will I meet the other two later on?"

"When they are ready to introduce themselves." firmly but kindly, Yoko said. "You are still very human but they will warm up to you once the changes are complete."

"Cecil was the one who brought me, everyone here." drying her tears of pebbles, Viva said. "He told us that he stays in this world due to an unfinished business."

"Cecil was a monster hunter in life." flatly, Yoko said. "He had killed hundreds of what humans considered to be monsters in his career." she sighed. "Only, near the end of his life, he realized that he was the monster and sacrificed himself to save Mark."

"He was the first monster here." managing a smile, Viva said.

"Mark helped Cecil build all four mansions, minus the fire mansion." serious, Yoko said.

"I helped build that one." beaming, Viva said.

Yoko grinned. "Viva may appear to be about twelve but stone lives a long time, she is actually twelve hundred years old." she explained. "She is practically immortal unless...."

Her words hung in the air as Viva began to tear up. I guessed that she would be vulnerable to some form of explosives. Again, I quickly changed the subject. "So Cecil is redeeming himself by finding a way to protect monsters instead of hunting them."

"That is correct." replied Cecil, appearing in the room. "Mark has breakfast ready, I suggest you bring Jon down so he can meet the others."

Viva beamed, taking my hand. "Come on, I can't wait for you to meet Vesper and Hannah."

"Who?" curious, I asked.
11431111211.title: continue.

114311112111.content:
"I think I should warn you about Vesper." solemnly, Yoko said. "He is not trusting of humans so do not be surprised if he is a bit hostile towards you."

"Will he hurt me?" gulping, I asked.

"If you give him an excuse." serious, Yoko said. "Vesper is a shadow person but he has been called a shadow monster, demon..." she sighed. "I think you get the idea."

"What is a shadow person?" curious, I asked.

Yoko paused at the door and turned to me, curious. "You don't know?" surprised, she asked.

I shook my head. "No, I don't."

"Have you ever seen something move out of the corner of your eye, turned, and saw no one there?" serious, she asked. I nodded. "What you saw was a shadow person."

"But what exactly are they?" stepping closer, I asked. "Are they ghosts?"

Yoko and Cecil smiled. "Not quite, lad." softly, Cecil replied. "A shadow person is of the undead; alive but not alive by 'human' definition."

"A shadow person can take on any physical form he or she wishes." chiming in, Yoko explained. "They can posses a person's shadow, make it solid to attack or defend that person." she sighed. "Only, they stick to the shadows as sunlight hurts them."

"You mean like a vampire?" following Yoko into the hall, I asked.

"Sort of." smiling, Viva said. "Vesper feeds off of people through their shadow."

"Their shadow?" confused, I asked.

"Or their reflection." shrugging, Yoko said. "Shadow people are supernatural; psychically feed off of a person, leaving them feeling weak; hungry and thirsty."

"Some relish the thrill of the hunt." serious, Cecil said. "They torment their victim, raising their adrenaline levels, which is like candy to them."

"I see..." gulping, I said.

"Don't worry." giggling, Viva said. "Vesper only feeds on me unless its to defend the mansion."

"He- He feeds on you!?" stunned, I asked. "Why!?"

"Stone golems have been known to grow to an immense size." serious, Cecil replied. "Viva wants to be as 'human' as possible, meaning keeping her size down." he smiled. "By allowing Vesper to feed on her every night, she retains her small size and Vesper is always well fed."

"I like to keep my girlish figure." giggling, Viva said.

I chuckled at that until Cecil spoke again.

"Vesper was not born a shadow person." with a sad tone, he said. "He was drained completely by one, transforming him." he sighed. "Fortunately, as he was not born that way, he retains his solid form but he can be a 'shadow' when he wishes.

"What of the other person, Hannah?" reaching the top of the stairs, I asked. "What is she like?"

"She is not your type, human." a cold voice replied.

I gasped and turned to see a boy in dark robes with a beautiful teen girl looking up at me from the bottom of the stairs. What made me shiver was that all I could see of the boy's face were two yellow glowing eyes.
114311112111.title: meeting Vesper and Hannah.

1143111121111.content:
"It's okay, Jon." calmly, the girl, Hannah said. "Come on down and join us for breakfast."

I turned to Hannah to find that she was about my height; thin but fit. She had long red hair with blond highlights that made her hair look almost like fire. A cute pink hair band kept her hair out of her eyes, her red eyes. Upon seeing this, I took a fearful step back but a gentle smile from her eased that a little and I relaxed some. Hannah was wearing loose fitting blue jeans, a tank top shirt and a long jacket, giving her a city girl look.

"He should not have been allowed in here until the change!" huffing, Vesper said. "He's a human!"

"Vesper, be nice!" scolding, Hannah said. "Our guest will not be human for long!"

"Until then, he is still human." more softly, Vesper countered.

"Do you remember what it was like to be human?" serious, Hannah asked. "To slowly change then be rejected by those you knew? Those you love?"

"Hannah..." moaning, Vesper said.

"No, Vesper." sternly, Hannah said. "He is going through the same nightmare you did; will you have him suffer as you did or will you help him?"

Vesper sighed then turned his glowing yellow eyes back onto me before throwing back his hood. I did not know what to expect, having never seen a shadow person before. I had thought of the possibility that he had no face but that vanished when I saw that he did. Vesper was much like Cecil, ghost like, only he translucent rather than transparent. That, and he was solid; I heard the floor creek as he took a step back, allowing us to come down. Upon meeting him face to face, he took my hand and gave it a quick shake. "I apologize... I did not mean to come off so cold."

I shrugged off the apology. "It's alright." softly, I said. "Yoko told me you had bad experiences with people after your... change. I can only hope I'll be accepted when I return home."

"I can understand you wanting to go back home to your family, Jon." sadly, Hannah said. "However, I fear you may suffer the same rejection as Vesper did."

"But I feel great." politely, I protested. "I never felt better."

"That's how it starts." serious, Vesper said. "Just wait until tonight."

I shivered at that, having no idea what I may become but paused as Yoko placed a firm hand onto my shoulder, startling me. "We can all discuss this over some breakfast." firmly but kindly, she said.

I descended the stairs and turned to Hannah, curious. She did not look like any monster I had heard of; in fact, she looked like a very attractive young woman. As if sensing my thoughts, Hannah giggled. "I am a Kitsune, Jon." smiling, she said. "Like Yoko, I am from Japan; we are the best of friends."

"A Kitsune?" confused, I asked. "That is a fox spirit, isn't it?"

Hannah smiled and took off her head band, allowing two fox like ears near the top of her head to rise before she removed her jacket, revealing three beautiful fox like tails that twitched slightly as she smiled at me. "See? I'm a Kitsune."

"A Kitsune, or fox spirit is considered a great prize due to the power they are said to possess." more seriously, Yoko said. "Hannah fled Japan as she did not wish to be owned by anyone."

"I see..." softly, I said. "I guess you all had it rough."

"Enough talk." firmly, Cecil said. "Let's all go eat."
1143111121111.title: continue.

11431111211111.content:
Again, I did not know what to expect when it came to monsters having breakfast. Upon being lead into the dinning room, I was surprised to see what seemed like a normal hodgepodge of breakfast items on a long table near a round table in the center of the room. "Don't pick out anything until you know what it is." smiling, Yoko said. "You might not like what you bite into."

"What do you suggest?" looking at the various, I asked. "The eggs look good."

Yoko giggled. "Well, you could eat one but I doubt you'll enjoy it." amused, she said. "Those are small animals I had caught and tightly spun in my silk to be dissolved so I may drink them."

I winced, hearing that but I could not hold down my curiosity. "What- What do they taste like?" I asked.

"Like chicken broth, I guess." shrugging, Yoko replied. "Want to try a sip?"

I winced again, uncertain. "Um... maybe later." politely, I said. "What are the others having?"

"You can have a few of my topsoil and worm sandwiches." smiling, Viva said. "You seemed to like the last one you had."

Hannah giggled. "You ate one of her sandwiches!?" surprised, she asked. "Did you really like it?"

"It wasn't too bad." blushing, I replied. "If I knew what it was, I probably would not have tried it."

"Saying that it wasn't too bad tells us that your tastes are already changing, Jon." serious, Cecil said. "I suggest you just pick something and try it. That will give us some clue as to what you are slowly transforming into."

I gulped at that then turned to the variety of foods in front of me. Viva took up a number of sandwiches with worms wiggling in them and a few wet stones from a dish of water. "Creek rocks are the best." turning to me, she said. "They are full of minerals, perfect for me to grow strong."

"I think they are a little too hard for me." smiling, you said. "So, polite pass..."

"Care for some ham or beef?" offering me a plate, Hannah asked. "There is plenty to share."

Normally, I would have accepted. Only, for some reason, the very sight of raw meat was unappetizing. "That's strange." curious, I said. "I usually love ham and beef but..."

"What on that table looks good to you?" walking up, Mark asked. "Don't think about what it is, just tell me what you think might taste good to you."

I sighed and turned back to the table. "The topsoil and worm sandwiches still sound pretty good." to Viva's giggles, I said. "The cinnamon sticks look good too."

"Those are hollowed out branches, stuffed with live insects, and capped with baked mud." with a grin, Mark explained. "They are my favorite food."

Yoko placed a number of her 'eggs' onto a plate. "Why not try one?" simply, she asked. "What do you have to lose?" she giggled, adding, "Besides maybe a stomach ache later."

"They are actually really good." taking a few, Mark said. "Just try one."

Albeit reluctantly, I took one of the bark and insect branches and two of the topsoil and worm sandwiches before turning to the table. "Where do I sit?"

"You can sit next to me." beaming, Viva said.

"No, that's Vesper's seat." firmly but kindly, Cecil said. "He has to eat too." he then turned to me. "You may sit between Yoko and Hannah."

Once everyone took their seats, Cecil lead everyone through grace before they all began to eat...
11431111211111.title: At breakfast.

114311112111111.content:
I picked up the insect stuffed branch with everyone watching and slowly took a bite. To my surprise, the branch seemed soft, almost like a burrito. As I chewed, I tried not to think what it was filled with but instead focused only on the taste. "It- It's pretty good." after swallowing, I said. "Considering what it's made of, I kind of like it."

"If you knew what was in a hot dog, you'd likely never eat it again." bemused, Hannah said. "However, this does not reveal much regarding what you are changing into but it does give us a few clues."

She then began to tear into the raw ham, giving a low growl as she tore a piece off and chewed it down before gripping the food with her mouth again to rip off another piece. It was actually cute, seeing such a cute girl rip into her food like a hungry kitten.

"Well, I don't think I'm going to be anything carnivorous." sighing, I said. "Considering what I now think about ham and beef."

"Don't be so sure about that." serious, Yoko said. she bit into one of her 'eggs' and slurped a few sips from the insides. "I do not like raw ham or beef but I can assure you I am very carnivorous." pausing, she added, "Your curiosity as to how my food tasted hints at that."

I shivered at the thought then gasped, seeing my hand. "What is this!?" almost shouting, I asked.

There was what looked like a green rash on my hand, it was oozing with a clear liquid, like water, only a little more viscus. I instinctively touched it and found that it was soft, like moss. Mark took a hold of my hand and looked at it. "The external changes are beginning." softly, he said. "That can only mean that the internal changes are almost done."

"What am I changing into!?" panicking, I asked. "Do any of you have a guess!?"

"It's difficult to tell without knowing more about you." serious, Yoko replied. "You may have been changing inside for quite a while before encountering us." taking a moment to think, she asked, "Which path were you using to take that shortcut?"

"Does it matter?" more worried about my rash, I asked.

"It matters more than you think." serious, Cecil replied. "The forest above us is not considered haunted because of us, there are creatures up there most humans would rather avoid."

"Which was one of the reasons why the mansions were built in this cavern system." chiming in, Vesper said. "They are deep with a twisting maze of tunnels but they can be navigated. The forest above serves as an extra measure to keep the curious away."

Then a small burp caused me to turn to see Viva had grown a full foot in height! She blushed, seeing my surprised expression. "Excuse me." softly, she said. she then turned to Vesper. "I think I'm ready for you to feed now."

Vesper nodded and I watched as he rose from his seat and stood behind her. He opened his mouth, revealing two long fangs! At first, I thought he was going to bite Viva on the neck but Vesper instead bit into nothing and Viva tilted her head, moaning quietly. This confused me until I saw their shadows. Vesper's shadow as biting Viva's shadow, he was feeding off her through her very shadow!

"Shadow people do not need to get close to their victim to feed." darkly, Cecil said. "All they need is for their shadow to touch theirs. That is what makes them so frightening to humans."

I continued to watch and saw that Viva was slowly shrinking down to her original size. Within minutes, Vesper walked away from Viva and took his seat. Viva let out another moan then took up a crick rock and began to nibble on it. "I'll be fine, you silly." seeing my worrisome expression, she said. "Vesper always gets full before I get too small."

I turned to Vesper who gave me a slight grin. "Don't scratch it." calmly, he said. "You'll only speed up the process, making it more painful."

"I still don't know what I'm changing into." tearing up, I said. "What if I become a..." I silenced myself.

"What if you become a threat?" looking at me, Cecil asked. I nodded and he smiled. "Do not worry, we know what to do, we will help you."
114311112111111.title: contine.

1143111121111112.content:
During breakfast, Yoko asked me again if I wanted to try one of her eggs. I winced but agreed to try a single sip. I took a little bite, again surprised by how soft it seemed and took in a tiny amount. Again, I was very surprised. "It does taste like chicken broth." almost whispering, I muttered.

Without thinking, I tossed the egg into my mouth and chewed it up before swallowing it down. For a moment, Yoko and Viva stared at me in shock. Before I realized what I had just done, they both fell into a fit of laughter.

"I can't believe you ate one of Yoko's eggs." giggling, Viva said. "You took it down, webbing and all."

"I didn't mind." shrugging, Yoko said. "Any major transformation takes a lot of energy."

"I guess I was more hungry than I thought." blushing, I said. "Do you think I was eating whatever I could to get that energy?"

"That's part of it." serious, Vesper replied. "I ate ravenously during my transformation but I can no longer eat as normal people do." he sighed, adding, "I miss the taste of a juicy steak."

"No one can do anything to change that, Vesper." patiently, Cecil said. "You could taste steak if you possessed a human and gain from its proteins by taking it from the host but..."

His voice trailed off but it was enough to remind me that I was the only human in the group; at least for the moment. I turned from Cecil to Vesper then sighed. "You can use me."

Vesper turned to me, surprised. "What!?"

"You can possess me and eat a steak." more loudly, I said. "I'm still human for now."

"As much as I am sure Vesper appreciates the offer, Jon, its just too dangerous." firmly, Cecil said. "He could devour you completely without realizing it, leaving you a shadow person, like him."

"I'm changing into something anyway." ruefully, I countered. "Besides... I think I can trust him."

Vesper gave me another surprised look but paused as Hannah placed a gentle hand onto his shoulder. "He has given you his permission, Vesper." calmly, she said. "Just do it and enjoy your steak."

The others voiced their approval, causing Cecil to sigh. "It looks like I'm out voted." frowning, he said. "Just do not say I did not give you fair warning."

With that said, Cecil prepared a steak, extra peppery to Vesper's request and placed it hot on a plate in front of me. "Okay, everyone remain quiet." firmly, Cecil said. "I want this to go smoothly."

Vesper, looking famished, stepped to my side then sat down onto my lap, his shadow like form moving easily into my body until his form completely covered my own. I looked down to see my hands move to take up the fork and knife. I cut a piece of the steak off and put it into my mouth. Upon chewing it, I heard a moan of delight from Vesper. "It's sooooo good!" happily, he said.

Upon finishing the steak, Vesper got up from the chair, leaving me unharmed but very hungry. "I think he emptied my entire stomach." grumbling, I said.

"There's plenty to eat, help yourself." smiling, Mark said.

Then, Vesper placed a hand onto my shoulder. "Thank you." smiling, he said. "That was the best steak, the only steak I had in years."

"My pleasure." smiling back, I said.

Vesper then walked away, leaving me to eat as Hannah then turned to me. "You have earned his friendship, Jon." whispering, she said. "Not bad for your first day among us."
1143111121111112.title: continue.

choices: Offer to help patrol the cave.
11431111211111121.content:
After I had eaten my fill, I helped clear the table and followed Mark to the kitchen where he began to wash the dishes. "Vesper is not a bad guy, once you get to know him." kindly, Mark said. "He's just learned to choose his friends very carefully."

"From what little I heard, I don't blame him." wincing, I said. "Did his entire town really turn against him? Did they really try to hurt him?"

Mark sighed. "Vesper's small town had been plagued by 'shadow people' for several years before he was turned into one of them." serious, Mark replied. "It was not anything he wanted but it still happened and he faced the town's wrath when he tried to return to some form of normal life."

"That's horrible..." gulping, I said. "They knew he was once human."

Mark shrugged. "He is not human anymore and, unfortunately, that is all that counts in the minds of many people these days." he said. "Yoko, Viva, Heather, and myself were born this way. We grew up dealing with the humans' fear and hatred of what they do not understand."

"Um.... Is there anything I can do to help around here?" trying to change the subject, I asked.

Mark smiled. "You can keep me company, for now, if you like."

"Okay, I guess." shrugging, I replied. "Were you the first person Cecil decided to help?"

"I was the second." washing a plate, Mark said. "Viva was the first. She often calls him 'daddy'."

"What's her story?" curious, I asked. "I heard she's twelve hundred years old but she acts like any ten or twelve year old girl."

Mark gave out a hiss like chuckle. "You need to remember that Viva is a rock golem, they age much more slowly than any human and most monsters." smiling, he said. "Viva will be a little girl long after you grow up and grow old."

"So her adopted human parents weren't killed...." mussing, I said.

Mark sadly shook his head. "Being human, they both died of old age." solemnly, he replied. "Viva does not yet understand that humans only live in the blink of an eye in the life span of a rock golem."

"I see..." sadly, I said. "that poor girl."

"She has Cecil now." drying his hands, Mark said. "He will never leave her so long as he is held to this world and even then, she has me and the others, including you."

"So what do we do now?" shrugging, I asked.

"Well, you could go help Hannah who is gathering fish by the lake." kindly, Mark said. "If you are not in the mood for fishing, you could help Yoko, she's setting up some webs for tonight."

"Why, what happens tonight?" worried, I asked.

"Tonight is the new moon." serious, Mark replied. "That is when a shadow person's power and hunger is the strongest. Vesper will be tempted to feed, the webs will alert us of his movements."

"But if he is a shadow person..." confused, I said. "How would webs help?"

"Yoko's webs pick up more than just movement, they detect energy as well." softly, Mark said. "She is the only one who can fight Vesper if the hunger takes control of him."

"How is that?"

"Vesper can not feed off of Yoko." with a smirk, Mark replied. "Her life energy is... shall we say, too spicy for his taste."

"Spider venom?" guessing, I asked.

Mark nodded. "Exactly." he then gave me a firm slap onto the shoulder. "I have to go help Viva patrol the cave. Why don't you go see if Hannah or Yoko needs any help."

What am I to do?
11431111211111121.title: continue.

choices: "Grab some of these needles and help me stretch this across"
114311112111111212.content:
"Well I'm not exactly good at fishing, and it sounds you guys you guys could use all the help you need with Vesper," I said as Mark finished his dishes.

"What a coincidence... I was heading that way myself," I jumped as a familiar figure appeared behind me. I sighed inwardly as Cecil strode into view. "We could always use an extra hand. Though you have your own troubles Jon, we understand if you'd rather turn in to deal with the changes."

I shook my head, "It's complicated... I owe you all... and honestly I'd rather be active while this happens... so I don't eat myself into a food coma and suddenly wake up as a monster like the rest of you." I cleared my throat a bit and scratched the back of my head. "N-no offense."

Mark laughed warmly, "None taken, it's what we all are after all."

Cecil nodded and offered a gentle smile laying a hand on my back though I didn't actually feel it. "She's just in the west wing, where your rooms are, I'll lead you there." He started to walk off before he paused and looked back to Mark. "Oh... before I forget... if time permits and everything goes smoothly I need to talk to you back where we found Jon, bring Viva along as well."

I followed Cecil quietly before trying to walk by his side, accidentally running my hand into his which passed through as if he wasn't their, though my new moss patch seemed a bit wilted afterwards. "Oh... uh sorry..."

Cecil raised his eyebrow before shrugging it off, "No worries, I haven't felt anything since my passing, just don't make a game it like Viva does," he said with a chuckle.

"A-alright... say why are you helping Yoko? I mean... I understand that's your whole goal, helping monsters and all... but can you actually do anything?" I tilted my head frowning a bit.

"Well Yoko can usually handle the putting up of her webs herself, but I always have to be there. You see she spins her webs extra thin so when Vesper gets out he won't notice them. However they also need to be strong enough to sense the energies he carries about. Which is why I'm here." Cecil said matter-of-factly.

"Oh... I think i get it... you and him are both mostly energy right? So since we can't have Vesper test them out we use you."

"Precisely, though I never enjoy this part of the month. I wish I never had to resort to this kind of tactics, trapping, and fighting the monsters i bring here, but it's unavoidable, when it's the only way I can truly help them..." I looked up at Cecil when he sad that and he had a deep look of sadness painted over his see through face.

"... You really regret hunting them don't you..." I winced... I never meant to say that though... the words just came out! "Cecil... I..."

"Yes... I really do... but there's no changing the past." Cecil said fading off and gliding faster down the hall.

"Took you long enough Cecil, what's the new kid doing here?" Yoko said hanging one of her webs across a doorway, "If Vesper starts early the kid's cooked."

"Well he wanted to help, might as well let him right? He said so himself he's turning into a monster anyway," Cecil said shrugging up at her.

Yoko sighed, "You do have a point, Hey kid if you want to help you can..."
114311112111111212.title: Help Yoko with her webs.

choices: Moving to a New Wing to continue the web hanging
1143111121111112121.content:
"W-what?" I was taken back as I looked at all the heavy antiques that lined the halls.

"I already said it, you can help by moving all the furniture in the hall, It needs to be done, I'll help when I get time." Yoko shook her head and returned to hanging her webs across the doorway.

Cecil smiled and shrugged, "Try to be careful with them, they're mementos from prior residents."

"R-right...." I groaned as i turned to the closest piece, which happened to be a large mahogany wardrobe, and sighed trying to psyche myself for what promised to be a grueling task. I've had to move these kinds of things before, when my grandmother moved out my family helped, but at that time it took five of us to just push the thing down the hall... sure I'm turning into a monster but there is no way I can move this. Hopefully i don't look too stupid doing this.

I placed my hands firmly on the wood and braced myself into the floor. This thing must be ancient, back when these things weren't just painted to look like wood. It must weigh a ton! Seriously there's no way I ca-AH! There was a loud screeching followed by a the sound of splintering wood just before I fell and knocked my head hard on the wooden floor. Slowly I peeled myself off of the floor and groaned rubbing my head, not noticing the green patches on my arms having spread further.

Cecil whistled from behind me with his hands in his pockets, "You sure did a number on my wardrobe Jon..... not to mention that side table."

I looked up at Cecil confused, "Wa-?" I turned back to where he was looking and my jaw hit the floor. Apparently when I tried to push the wardrobe, I pushed it hard enough that it slid across the floor a good few feet, ran into a side table, and then crushed the table by slamming into the wall on the other side of the hall. "W-w-what happened?"

"Well Jon, if I had to say something, it seems to me your changes are happening faster than expected, and you now have the strength to give viva a fight in an arm wrestling contest." Cecil walked over inspecting the damage in his furniture.

Yoko, still hanging her webs, looked over, "Well.... I guess that removes some of the options he's turning into..... wish I could move stuff like that," she said the last part under her breath.

Cecil sighed and looked over at me and shook his head as if he expected this to happen. "Don't worry Jon... I'll get this fixed, but if you're going to keep helping us... we gotta get that strength back in check till you can use it safely."

I felt my face turning red and frowned, "U-uh sorry Cecil," the man just chuckled and laid a ghostly hand on my head before going back to helping Yoko. His hand held no weight and I didn't really feel it but, the gesture was nice I guess. I picked myself off the ground and, while still embarrassed, I went back to moving the furniture, thankfully though with only minor damages this time.
1143111121111112121.title: "Start by Moving the furniture"

choices: Someone's In my room I can't Move!
Vesper's Yelling somewhere down the hall!
11431111211111121211.content:
After a long day of simply moving furniture and hanging webs, I was surprised when I wasn't all that tired, though I wasn't exactly ready to run a marathon afterwards. It made me nervous being able to do all of this so suddenly... yesterday I got winded after a long game of dodge ball during team sports. Cecil must have noticed my strength was troubling me as he walked over and laid a ghostly hand on my shoulder and offering a kind smile. Honestly I'm so glad I ended up here, sure I don't know them, but just having all these people around me who are like me, it makes me feel safe, something I bet allot of 'turning' people wished they had. Finally one last web was mounted across a hallway, just in time two as apparently the sun had just set since Hannah was returning with a basket full of fish.

"Ah... finally... I know we have to do this pretty often, but I can never get used to how long it takes," Cecil chuckled to himself and inspected their work, "Well there goes my plans for tonight," he half joked as he rubbed his head.

The Tsuchigumo girl walked up behind him and placed her hands on her hips, "Since when do YOU have plans, all you ever do is float around the place and ask us questions about facebook," Yoko huffed.

Cecil smiled widely at here, sharp teeth and all (still can't get over those), "Well since Jon showed up of course, we do have a massive hole near our entrance after all, don't want someone getting hurt again~" Yoko shrugged at that accepting the answer to be a rather accurate one. I smiled at them, enjoying their company, especially since they took my mind off my current changes, but as I began to approach them and hopefully find out what to do next, my legs simply gave out and my eyes rolled back into my head as I plummeted to the ground. The world was all fuzzy as I heard the rush of feet coming towards me and strong arms lifting me up... must have been Yoko. I couldn't make out what they were saying but they seemed worried, at least I think they were. After that they must have started moving me back to my room, my vision cleared just enough, but my body remained limp and I was just so tired, I looked up to see Yoko's stern expression as she carried me down the hall, Cecil was nearby who offered a smile just before he left down another way, to another wing.

Eventually Yoko made it to my room, surprisingly being gentle as she laid me on the mattress and pulled sheets around me. Despite her bitter attitude and stern looks, she was nice deep down. I tried to speak to her but I barely had enough energy to tilt me head and have it roll to the side. "Don't speak," she said firmly, as she laid a hand on my head, "You're burning up again... you must have not eaten enough after vesper drained you... get some sleep Jon, I'll tell Cecil what happened..." After that, before she even left I nodded off. A few seconds later I jumped awake...

What happened?
11431111211111121211.title: Later that Night

114311112111111212112.content:
What seemed like seconds later, I jumped awake hearing a number of muffled voices in the hall outside of my closed door. They all sounded frantic; something was very wrong. I guessed that Vesper was on the prowl, as the others had warned me might happen that night. Only then I heard Vesper scream just outside my door, "Jon! Wake up!"

My eyes sprung open to reveal vines and branches everywhere in my room! I screamed at the sight then screamed again as they all rushed towards me! My closed door was ripped off its hinges as vines and branches poured into the room and wrapped themselves around me. "Help!" Desperate, I screamed. "Someone help me!"

For a moment, I thought I would suffocate under the seemingly endless twisting of vines and branches but for some reason, I felt no pain. As my panic subsided, I realized that I had completely transformed into my monster form. Only why was I attacking my friends in my sleep? Yoko entered shortly after the doorway was cleared and began to pour water onto me. The water was warm but it still sent a chill through me. "Hey! What are you doing?!"

Yoko poured another pitcher of water onto me. "I was right when I said you did not get enough to eat." She gave me a slight grin. "You gave everyone a real fright when you 'branched out' looking for a drink of water, Jon."

"Very funny." Pouting, I said. "I didn't hurt anyone, did I?"

Vesper came into view. "No one has hurt; just startled out of a night's rest. Thanks to the steak, I was well fed so the hunger did not effect me." He rubbed his chin in thought. "You turned out rather unique."

This peeked my curiosity. "What do I look like?"

Yoko helped me into a sitting position and handed me a mirror. I had soft, moist, dark green moss for skin and dense vines for muscles. I had branches for hands like Mark and deep set eyes with glowing jewels like Viva. My hair was made up of leaves and my finger and toe nails were made of flat stones. "What- What am I?" Staring at my reflection, I asked.

Vesper smiled. "I believe you are a..."
114311112111111212112.title: Vesper's Yelling somewhere down the hall!

1143111121111112121121.content:
Vesper smiled. "I believe you are a forest golem."

"How did this happen?" Stunned, I asked. "Could Mark or Viva..."

"I fear this started long before you met us." Gently, Yoko said. "We all agree that Viva only awakened what had lied dormant within you."

"All golems naturally yearn to return to the place of their birth when they come of age." Softly, Mark said. "Has your mother ever spoke of your father?"

I did not like where this was going. "No, mom rarely spoke of my dad." Worried, you said. "Are you telling me that he was a golem?"

"It's very possible." Wincing, Yoko replied. She sighed, seeing tears in my eyes. "You transformed very quickly after coming into contact with Viva and Mark."

"It normally takes weeks." Chiming in, Mark said. "I have seen it happen; my parents changed a boy they found dying in their woods." He sighed. "I miss them and my little brother, who was that boy."

I gulped. "What happened to them?"

Mark was silent for a moment then replied with two words. "Forest fire."

I bowed my head, tears falling. "Sorry..."

"It was nearly a century ago." Softly, Mark said. "I have moved on." His smile returned. "Let us now focus on you, shall we?"

I turned back to him and slowly nodded. "If my dad was a golem, why was I not born one?"

"Your mother is human." Simply, Yoko said. "Hence you were born with that outward appearance."

"Only you were a golem on the inside." Entering the room, Viva said. "I sensed you were one but I wasn't sure so I helped you anyway."

I sighed, a half smile forming onto my face. "When you thought I was running from someone."

"I said I was sorry." pouting, Viva said.

"It's okay." Patiently, I said. "I guess it was bound to happen sooner or later."

"It is best it happened here with us." Serious, Vesper said. "Otherwise, you would have experienced the same pain and betrayal I did when I was changed."

"So what happens to me now?" Worried, I asked. "I can't go back home like this!"

"You have a home here." Smiling, Viva said. "Your mom will understand. She fell in love with a golem."

"How can a human and a golem...?" Wincing, I asked.

Yoko smiled. "Golems are magical creatures." Calmly, she explained. "They can become human for a short period of time." She shook her head. "It takes much practice and a lot of energy. Still..."

"Love can make anyone do incredible things." Appearing in the room, Cecil said. "Welcome to Monster Manor, Jon Que."

I returned his smile. "Thank you. I guess this is my home now."

Cecil sighed, noting my sadness. "We all went though this transition, whether we were born this way or changed by another." Serious, he said. "We will help you adjust. First, it's time for some breakfast."
1143111121111112121121.title: Your true form emerges.

choices: Bring her back to the Living!
Enter Death's Realm further with the soul to explore!
115.content:
The first thing I saw, were stars... Shooting stars. Millions of them, racing through the portal of darkness. It was the most beautiful site to behold. Shimmering emerald, magenta and crimson lights emitted from those stars, were entwining themselves to form one body of intricate rainbow lights, while others zipped towards the 'end' - which was currently blocked from my view.

Where was I? I just stood there, gaping at the splendour of it all...

This was curious. Was it another dream? Recently, this so-called place had frequently visited my dreams, or my unconscious state of mind. I wonder...

Under some unknown impulse, I reached forward and attempted to grab a single shooting star. I missed, and it shot past me, teasing me for my sluggishness. Groaning, I rolled my eyes as it disappeared into the distance.

Whatever, I could always try again.

So I did. I lunged forwards this time, and clapped down my fingers on a passing star, before securing tight between my palms. HA! GOTCHA!

The star was still bright, very bright, which reminded me of a car on a great load of fuel. It was one of the newest and brightest stars here. Perhaps it was my imagination, but it seemed to be struggling, struggling vigorously in my grasp.

"LET ME GO!" A young girl's voice yelled from the star. "LET ME GO THE BEYOND!"

"What?" I asked, surprised and interested. "I have no idea what you're talking about."

"I'm dead. And I would like my soul to rest in peace," the star whispered in melancholy.

"You're dead?"

The star agreed. "I just died very recently. I'm a soul. I think this is the earliest stage of death. The limbo. LET ME GO! I need to pass it!"

I was puzzled. "Is everyone here dead?"

"Yes," the voice whispered sadly. "See those bright stars? We are all newly dead souls, racing towards the beyond, where we can forever rest in peace."

"So the brighter the star... the more recent the person's death?" I figured, completely entralled.

"I guess," the star said. "I ANSWERED YOUR QUESTIONS SO LET ME GO!"

"Wait." This was all very interesting, but I had to know something. "One last thing. Why am I here?"

"I'm just a poor dead soul," the star pouted from beneath my palms. "How do expect me to know? You look rather alive to me, poking your nose into businesses which are not yours. Now let me head on to the BEYOND!"

"I didn't ask to be here!" I snapped, angry now. "So am I dead?"

The star seemed to be staring right at me. "No, I don't think so," she said, awed. "Your soul is too bright... I think you're alive..."

"So means I can go back?" I asked excitedly. "I can... well, be alive?"

"I suppose," the star drawled boredly. "If you don't trespass too far into the territory of the dead."

And as the star said that, I could feel my surroundings slowly sifting, slowly changing. Even though I hadn't a clue what was really going on, somehow, deep within me, I knew I was returning to the 'Realm of the Alive' where I truly belonged. Yes, I was going back! Finally! I didn't fancy living among the newly dead any longer.

The star apparently felt it too, because it got frantic, thrashing under my grip.

"LET ME GO, QUICK! DON'T BRING ME BACK TO THE WORLD! I DON'T WANT TO LIVE AGAIN! I WANT TO BE FREE IN THE BEYOND!" It yelled.

"You mean I can do that?" I asked befuddled.

The star appeared both urgent and uncertain. "I... think so... You seem capable... I don't know... I am not too 'into' death yet, I suppose.... But the fact that you're here and alive is a pretty great feat already."

"Wow, if I could bring you back alive..."

"DON"T YOU DARE!" The soul screamed a blood curdling cry. "LET ME GO ON MY JOURNEY NOW!"

This conversation had thoroughly shaken me up. So apparently, I had suddenly entered 'Death's Realm' in which the dead had to take before they reached this peaceful place called the 'Beyond'. And according to the star, I had a choice whether to bring her back to the Living, or free her and let her carry on to the Beyond. It would be amazing! If what she said was truly reliable, then perhaps I could bring all sorts of people back from the dead! I could stop my loved ones from dying if I caught them!

I was scared, but curiosity got the better of me.

And suddenly, I didn't feel like freeing this star anymore. I felt like experimenting. I felt like replenishing her life, and letting her start anew.

My surroundings were shifting again, even more, at a greater scale. Soon, I would be back where I was, a normal teenager, in a normal school, with a normal sister and a normal mom.

But before that, I had one decision to make. A decision which would surely affect my life in many ways.

Free the soul or not to free?
115.title: Somewhere else.

choices: Agree to try to send her back.
1152.content:
I changed my mind last minute, deciding to be merciful and free the soul, but it was too late. One second I was in the middle of tons of shooting souls, and in the next second, I found myself lying on my back, head whoozy and all. My eyes fluttered open uncertainly and tried to adjust to my unusually dark surroundings.

Now, where was I again?

I grimaced in pain as I straightened my legs. Now, that certainly hurt like mad. Experimentally, I shifted my leg once more, only to have a nasty electric shock surge through my ankles. Oh darn, so it was fractured.

"YOU IDIOT!" A familiar girl's voice screeched from underneath my clenched palm.

"Woah, woah!" I gasped. "I can't believe- What...?"

The soul cursed me every single nasty word in the dictionary, before yelling, "AT LEAST LET GO OF ME!"

Too stunned to speak, I obediently did as I was told.

The star-like soul seemed to leap off my open palm before bursting into an even blindingly bright light, growing larger and larger, till... till it formed a young girl, who looked about a year younger than I was. I couldn't really see her features in the dark, but I could tell that man, she looked crazily mad. Mad at me, that was.

"Ass!" The girl cried out indignantly, before kicking me over and over again at my fractured ankle.

Wincing in pain, I begged, "Stop! Oww! Stop please!"

To my surprise, she did. And suddenly, fear flickered across her features.

"You... brought me back from the dead. I..." She inspected herself with shock. "I'm alive..."

"I don't know... I'm sorry..." I apologized uncertainly.

"I'm not gonna forgive you," she snapped. Then she looked to me. "So where are we?" she demanded.

"My best guess is that we're in a hole. And a really deep one, I'm guessing."

"What?" Her eyes bulged in disbelief "You rob me from my chance to rest in peace and put me in damn hole?"

"I didn't do it on purpose," I replied in my defense. "I fell in here.... by accident."

She calmed down, before straining her neck upwards trying to estimate the exact height of the hole. "So it's Tessa to the rescue again," she groaned. "Alright, what are you waiting for? Get onto my back and climb out!"

That girl named Tessa was blind. "If you haven't noticed, my leg is fractured!"

"Oh, oopsies."

Then, an idea struck me. It required me to be self-sacrificial, but I was willing to risk it. Besides, it was dark, and there would probably be no search teams out in search of me. I didn't fancy my chances staying out in the woods all night. And don't forget, Mom would definitely go nuts if I didn't return tonight.

"Get on my shoulders," I told her. "Pull yourself out."

"Are you serious?" She asked me incredulously. "Then you?"

"Follow the path down after you get out," I directed her. "There's a house at the end. It's my house. Inform someone there, and ask them to rescue me!"

She stared at me thoughtfully for a moment. "Alright," she agreed finally. "Get down on fours."

It was harder said then done. Every single tiny movement caused my poor fractured limb to tremble with agony. But in the end, I succeeded anyway, panting away.

"Hurry!" I pleaded.

Tessa obviously deliberately took her own sweet time to climb onto my back to pay me back from my actions earlier.

"Hurry!" I screamed this time. "I'm breaking, dammit!"

She cast one scornful look at me and hauled herself out of the hole. Really, it surprised me that she managed it. Even on my back, the opening of the hole was more than a head higher than her. She must have had a lot of hidden muscles.

"Done," she informed me, arrogantly. "I'm out. You alright down there?"

"Yeah," I gasped. "Now go inform them!"

An evil grin crossed her features. Uh oh, bad news. Now what? Maybe I shouldn't have so readily trusted a dead girl. Too late to regret.

"On one condition," she smiled evilly. "You send me back to the Dead where I belong- back to the limbo."

WHAT? I didn't even know how I got in there in the first place! How'd you expect me to know how to get back?

"I... don't know how..." I admitted truthfully. "Sorry."

"Well then," The girl's smile faded. "Sorry to you then. You're staying down there!"

The girl turned to leave, before retracing her steps and returning to the entrance of the hole. "Please!" she begged all of the sudden. "There's no other way back! Only you! You have to! I can't believe I'm stuck with an idiot like you!"

"OK..." I said a bit too quickly.

"Okay?" She asked excitedly. "Will you? Will you? Will you send me back?"

I didn't know what to say, my mouth felt extremely, extremely dry. I could send her back, send her back and let her rest in peace in the 'Beyond' where she so wished. Or I could refuse. She had no choice, she had to stick around me, and if I died, all her chances of returning would be severed. She had to keep me alive at all cost. And I admit it, I did like this girl's company despite her rough demeanour.

And then I thought of an unusually mean thought: I could make her serve me. If I could bring back souls from the dead, I could make them serve me by promising them that I would return them to the dead.

The moment I thought it, I immediately mentally slapped myself. How cruel of me! How could I?

So what? So what now?

I had the power to agree or refuse, what should I do?

12.content:
Brandon Wickers, along with his copy-cat gang, made it a point to 'greet' me everyday. When I say copycat, I'm not kidding. Recently, Wicker had been forced by his mom to wear braces, and within a week, it became some sort of 'fashionable trend' to take after. And if I recall, two weeks earlier, braces were supposed to be the most degrading sort of metallic device ever.

So the moment Wicker made it a point to 'greet me', it became a new fad.

"Hey there witchy-girl!" 'Wicked' would call from the other end of the class every morning.

And his little cronies would echo the same sentence after him. If you hadn't listened to that for the past three years of your life, you would have thought it was some sort of cheer or something.

The bastards. "Get some new lines!" I would yell back.

And a flicker of amusement would appear on his features.

That happened everyday.


One day, I finally plucked up my courage to ask him a question which had been troubling me for the past three years. How coincidental, for our Biology teacher had forced us to be science partners for some sort of Bunsen Burner experiment. Alright, I admit it, I was terribly afraid of fire.

"See, see!" Wicked exclaimed accusingly. "You're doing it again!"

"Shut up and light the Bunsen Burner," I ordered him, having no idea what the hell he was talking about.

Wicked looked me in the eye. "Dare you to on the Bunsen Burner, witchy-girl."

"Well," I bit my lip. I was so NOT going to admit I was scared of fire. Not when he was looking at me in such a condescending manner. "Errr..."

"Knew it!" He said triumphantly. "Witches fear fire!"

I feigned a sigh. "Always knew you were missing something up there. I wonder..." I pretended to think. "Of course! Must be your brain eh?"

He ignored me. "That's why they burnt witches in the past," Wicked explained gleefully. "Tied them to a stick and fried them with fire."

Fine, I did make a mistake of sharing that I came from a long line of Wiccans for my Elementary School show and tell. Really, it wasn't my fault. I just thought that I might be somewhat interesting and fetch me a high grade. But who knew? Not only did I barely pass, but next thing I knew, Wicked and his gang had adjusted from not noticing me at all, to labeling me 'witchy-girl'. Old habits die hard, three years later, he still sticks to the nickname.

"Are you done yet?" I groaned.

"Wait for the good part," he continued with sadistic excitement. "One day, I'm gonna sneak up on you with a cross and BOO-YAH!"

I'm supposedly good with dealing with annoying guys which come around to bug me daily, but with Wicked, its different. He completely redefines the meaning of annoying, and totally pisses the hell out of me. It's amazing, his skills.

"And then I'll take a bunch of holy water and-"

SHUT UP! ENOUGH WAS ENOUGH! I was boiling mad now. At the moment, I was wishing I was really a witch. If I were a witch, I would have turned him into a toad there and then. But unfortunately, I wasn't.

Then, despite my blind rage, I swore I felt a strange sensation of energy... or power... surge through me. I felt like I could control everything and anything at my will. I felt invincible... Hah?

And suddenly, Wicked looked downright afraid. Maybe it was just a figment of my imagination. But he did looked rather unlike himself.

"You have to explain yourself," Wicked suddenly whispered gently. "I've always kinda known that... Besides your witchy green eyes and black hair, you can... OK. Admit it, you ain't normal either."

"You're crazy!"

"My family has known the Wilds for generations."

"So?" I asked incredulously. "That doesn't explain anything!"

Wicked chewed his lip thoughtfully for a moment. "OK, you tell me your secret, and I'll tell you mine," He randomly piped out.

What secret? This guy was plain weird. Maybe his 'secret' explained why he had been picking on me ever since he learnt I had 'Wiccan' blood in my veins according to him. If that was the case, I would definitely like to know.

In the background, the Biology teacher yelled, "ON THE BUNSEN BURNER ALREADY!"

Wicked rolled his eyes, winked at me, and switched on the Bunsen burner with a flick of the lighter. That idiot, he should have done it earlier then.

But, something else was troubling my mind. I wondered what secret?

"We're not star-crossed," I rolled my eyes. "We have to actually like each other for us to qualify as star-crossed lovers."

Something unusual flickered momentarily in Wicked's expression, but I shrugged it off. That was just him being weird again.

"Right, so... star-crossed enemies?" Wicked piped up hopefully.

For the #300th time today, I rolled my eyes. Was it just me, or did I seem to do that a lot around Wicked? Wicked's retardedness never failed to boost my ego; to make me realize that I'm a normal person despite all my shortcomings; that Wicked was the real mentally unsound patient here. But... despite his apparent usefulness, he still annoyed the shit out of me, and I still hated him.

"That's not the main point," I tried to coax him onto 'the-path-of-a-normal-person'. "The main point is-"

"Flipping Fibonacci!" Wicked exclaimed excitedly. "I got it!"

I mentally prepared myself to endure something incredibly stupid. And as it turned out, I was right in a way.

"Both our families should have dinner together, shake hands, be friends," Wicked suggested. "And hopefully, that clears the feud."

I swore my IQ dropped by at least ten points at that. "Didn't you just tell me ten seconds ago that our families bear many millenniums worth of grudges?"

"Germany hated USA (a.k.a us). But they still had some peace treaty right?"

"Right, and btw, its called the Treaty of Versailles. And everyone, besides you, knows that Germany screwed the treaty over and started World War 2 anyway," I countered intellectually. At least I listened in class, unlike Wicked, who apparently had completely no clue of his own country's turbulent history. In fact, I bet he didn't even know the name of our current President. That guy only cared about three things: himself, himself, and his Call of Duty video game.

"So," He began to digest the information in bite-sized bits. "So the moral of the story is that-"

"-is that: Your crap plan isn't going to work," I muttered darkly. "Newsflash."

People around us had already began filing out of the Chemistry lab. I gathered my labcoat, pencil case, and worksheets from the table, and removed myself from my seat. Talking to Wicked only had me learn to things: we were now star-crossed enemies, and that his IQ was lower than I had expected. At this rate, I wasn't going to find out anything about... our clashing families, which of course might cost us our lives later on.

At the beginning, when Wicked had taken a snipe at my 'witchness' as usual, and then suddenly went 'oh, by the way, we're enemies. Your family consist of witches, and mine of witch-hunters. AND... I'm supposed to kill you'.', I just stared at him like a fish out of water, gaping for breath. But later on, when he had explained the situation more thoroughly (with me cross-referencing the information with my family background, behaviours and experience), I began to slowly take his word with more than a pinch of salt. And when I had finished adding sodium hydroxide to the dish of hydrochloric acid, I came to realize that the gravity of the situation was serious, and that this wasn't something to fool around about.

And when our solution was bubbling, I decided to engage in actual conversation with Wicked - one that didn't include me cussing at him, and him laughing at my expense.

"Can I ask you something?" I asked, just before I left the class.

"You're going to ask it anyway," Wicked replied as a matter-of-factly. "There's no stopping nerds like you."

I ignored him completely. "Why didn't you... you know, kill me while you could?" My mind began to flash to countless of situations where he could have simply finished me off, like the time I sprained my ankle during Physical Education...

"I don't attack girls," He replied steadily. "That's against the manly code of manliness."

For once in my life, I was glad that Wicked was retarded; glad that he had retarded values; glad that he had a retarded manly code of manliness. To hide my relief, I said, "Doesn't your manly code of manliness include not teasing girls too?"

"If it did, I'd quit," Wicked told me seriously. "They can't ban a necessity."

I rolled my eyes for the third time that morning. Since his answer wasn't worthy of a reply from me, I soundlessly grabbed my belongings and stomped out of class.

Hey there, I'm Tom Graves, but I prefer that you just call me Tom. You know, life can be really random sometimes, you know? Like how something perfectly normal is happening, and something super crazy happens right afterwards. Well, my story is kind of like that, only difference is that there's a bigger emphasis on the term "crazy". You could say that something happened to me. Something that completely changed my world point of view. And believe me, it's never gonna be the same again...

It all started on that day. It was the beginning of summer, where I woke up around 9 a.m. or so in the morning. I live with my mom and dad, along with Scott, my little brother, and my dog Rex. Although Scott seems to have a habit of calling him Rexxy, I'm sure it's perfectly normal. He's only like 6 or something. Anyway, I woke up to the sound of my alarm clock, which I've gotten used to setting every night. I said good morning to Rex, who I always keep in my room. He's a healthy Labrador Retriever, in case you were wondering. And of course, he barked up at me and gave my face a bath with his tongue. I was on my way to the shower for a real bath when I started feeling a little itchy. It wasn't anything bad, because it felt like one of those occasional itches that everyone gets every once in a while. But the thing was, wherever I scratched, it came back somewhere else. I wasn't really worried or anything, but I hurried a little to the shower, just in case.

While I was bathing, I was really relieved to find the itch was gone. Maybe Rex was starting to get flees? Hope not. Bathing him is a real hassle. Anyway, funny thing about what happened while I was shampooing my hair. I couldn't help but notice my hair seemed a little longer than I remember when I went to bed last night. It was weird, I admit, or maybe it's just a case of a faulty memory? Nah. After my shower, I was brushing my teeth to get rid of that morning breath. That was when I found something that started to creep me out a little. It was my teeth. My canines, to be exact. They were a little longer, and maybe even a little more pointed than before. Or maybe it was just the mirror playing tricks on me. Yeah, that's gotta be it.

Anyway, I still can't help but feel that something was really off about me today. It could just be my serves, since I've been so excited for summer vacation this year. I went back to my room to spend a little play time with Rex before breakfast. And that was when I knew that something really weird is going on around here. When I opened the door, Rex bounded up to me like he always does, but then he stopped right in front of me. That's never happened before.

"Hey, what's wrong Rex?" I asked.

But he didn't move. He didn't even reply in anyway. No bark, no growl, no yelp, no nothing. He just stood there with his tail between his legs, like he was...Afraid of me.

"Rex? What's the matter? It's me, Tom! Your friend, remember?"

I tried to get a little closer, and he suddenly ran under the bed. I was starting to panic a little bit, but I tried to keep a calm face the whole time. I had to lie down to see him under the bed, cowering in the shadows.

"Rex! It's me, Tom! Please come out! You're starting to scare me!"

I wanted to find someway to make him come out. Rex has never done anything like this before, ever! I went to my table, where I would always keep his favorite chew toy on top of it. When I grabbed it, I saw something even weirder. I keep a hand mirror on the side of the table, and the reflection was what I found weird. In case you're wondering, I got that mirror as a birthday present from one of my aunts, okay? Anyway, I picked up the mirror and saw myself, only it didn't seem like myself to me. My hair was longer by at least half an inch, my canines were even sharper, and worst of all, were my eyes. They didn't seem human anymore. My pupils were slits, like an animal's! Now I know why he was afraid of me! It was because I don't even look like myself anymore! My first thought was to find the reason why I was turning into this...thing, but first thing's first. I have to convince Rex that I'm still me. I rushed back to my bed and held out the chew toy, making sure that my face was out of sight.

"Here Rex, I've got your favorite chew toy! Come on, I won't hurt you, I promise!"

At first, I wasn't sure that this was gonna work, but he slowly came out and saw me.

"Don't be afraid Rex. It's me, Tom. I won't hurt you, and I never will, okay?"

He sniffed my hand a little before he took the toy out of my hand. I petted him a bit, just to help make him feel better. It took a few minutes before he was convinced that I was still myself. I felt glad for that.

"I'm sorry for scaring you like that. I don't know what happened. But I'm gonna look for an answer, and everything will be back to the way it was. Alright?"

He licked my face a couple times and hugged me. I definitely needed that. Little did I know that everything won't be going back to normal that easily. What happened next was a knock at my door, which I really hated, since I was having a moment with my dog here. Anyway, it was...

"Tom, aren't you going down for dinner?" he asked.

"Uh, I'm just spending some time with Rex here, that's all!" I called back.

"Tom, you know that everyone has to be at the dinner table whenever we have our meals. Come on out already."

"But dad, I-I'm a little busy in here!"

"Busy with what?"

"U-uh...Personal stuff!"

"...Is it anything you can discuss with your old man?"

"Um...Uh, it's a little, er...Complicated."

"...Tom, I respect your privacy by knocking and talking to you through the door, but as your parent, I'm worried about you, so I'm coming in anyway."

Crud! The first thing that came to mind was to hide, so I jumped into my bed covers and hid my head underneath. I heard the door creak open as my father walked into the room.

"Tom, if there's any problem you have, I'm here if you ever wanna talk about it."

"You don't understand! See, I'm, uh...Changing."

"Changing?"

"Y-yeah...Please understand, but something weird is happening to me and..."

I couldn't finish my sentence. It felt like the words refused to come out of my mouth. But it didn't matter anyway, as dad pulled the covers off of me and saw what I looked like. I just stared back at him, afraid of how he was gonna react. But what he did was like the opposite of what I thought he was going to do! He just sat there on the edge of the bed and looked at me in the eye.

"Son, I think it's about time I told you something about my side of the family."

At first, I was pretty surprised that he was perfectly calm with all of this. I just sat up and listened to what he told me.

"You see Tom, my side of the family isn't what you would call normal. You see, it's a little hard to explain, but...Well, our bloodline contains latent werewolf blood."

"Wait...Did you just say werewolf blood? As in those man-eating monsters of the night werewolves?"

"Yes, but that description's actually a little stereotypical. You see, every generation gives birth to a werewolf child, but only the first born receives this gift. These people will begin to turn into their true forms once they come of age. My guess is it's about your time now."

"So let me get this straight. We have an entire family who's first borns, including me, are all werewolves!?"

"That's right son. Your mother already knows this, so you don't have to hide it from her. But try not to scare your brother, alright?"

"D-dad! What am I gonna do!? This means that I'm gonna turn into a snarling, blood-thirsty monster every full moon!"

"Now calm down. That's just another movie stereotype the media invented. You keep all of your memories and sanity while you're transformed, and you don't need a full moon to transform either. You can actually change no matter what time of the day it is, but you will change on full moon nights."

"Hey, how do you know all this?"

"Why, I lived with my older brother for years until I moved out, remember?"

"Oh yeah, uncle Daniel. No wonder his Halloween costume was so scary two years ago."

"There, see? There's nothing to worry about Tom. Once your body has finished changing, you'll learn to turn back human soon afterwards."

"Thanks dad. I'm really glad you explained all this to me."

I hugged him, thinking about what he told me, and he hugged me back. When we broke, my dad told me that I can have breakfast in bed, just for today so I don't have to see Scott and accidentally scare him. As he closed the door, Rex jumped up on to me. I was glad he wasn't scared of me. I petted him a bit more, when my hands started getting all twitchy. I looked at them as these patches of hair...Fur...Whatever were growing on it! The hair, I mean fur, was a darkish brown in colour, and they were slowly spreading up to my wrists! Not only that, but my fingernails were growing longer and sharper, growing over my fingertips and making them look like claws! I looked at my palms as parts of them, along with this side of my fingers, were turning black and leathery, like the foot pads of a dog! The changes suddenly stopped at my wrists. My forearms were still human, but it looked like I had wolf paws for hands! Well, I'm not really sure if I can call them paws, because I still have opposable thumbs. I looked back at Rex, sitting in front of me. He wasn't scared really, but more like...Um, concerned is the closest word I can think of.

"Don't worry Rex. Once this is all over, I can just change back into the Tom you used to know."

He nuzzled my head a little as I stroked his back. I was really hopeful that this wasn't going to take too long to finish. I just wanted my old life back...
