Tina agreed, as a muffled growl erupted from her stomach. She hadn't figured she'd be so hungry.

"Father takes his meals up in the tower, so I'm afraid it'll only be the two of us this evening."

Tina was too distracted by her sudden hunger to take note of what Wylie said. Ever the gentleman, he set forth promptly. Wylie snapped his fingers and pushed against one of the stainless steel walls of the laboratory. It parted to reveal a hallway lined with more doors. As the two of them made their way through this labyrinthine passage, Tina started to feel woozy. Wylie corralled her with one arm and escorted her into the dining hall. Though several massive tables lined the walls, an intimate setting for two sat center stage. Two meals hid beneath silvery metal tins. She could smell them from here, and she started to drool.

She almost flew to the table in the pursuit of food. He moved close behind, and withdrew the domed prison that held captive the meal. To Tina's surprise was a banquet fit for a king. And most of it (at least on her end) was red meat! Along with the typical steak, there was pork, lamb, and a few other foods Tina couldn't identify. Though it was a bigger buffet than she'd ever had, she scarfed it all down. Bones and all. Wylie merely grinned as he sipped at his drink and picked apart some other creature on his plate at a relaxed pace. As Tina nearly licked her plate clean, she finally caught sight of herself and sheepishly pushed herself away from it. Her face burned a bright red as she coolly sipped down water.

"Sorry, I guess I was hungrier than I thought."

"It's no trouble. Good to see you have an appetite."

The look he gave her after that comment embarrassed Tina further. She had no idea what had come over her. Her attention moved to anything but his gaze. She looked at her hand. At least her nails looked like a girl's should, if they weren't a little too sharp. She'd try and file them down when she got home. Tina mindlessly tried to pick some gunk out of her teeth, only to scratch her tongue! Discreetly, she tried to feel the tip of her teeth, and noticed an unnatural point to them. Wylie's eyes caught her again, and she coyly tried to laugh it off. He smirked along with her.

"If you need a moment, the washrooms are behind me."

"Oh, no, no, I'm fine."

After Wylie finished his dinner, he brought out a bottle of what resembled red wine from nowhere. He poured Tina a glass, but she was apprehensive.

"We shouldn't be drinking, we're underage!"

"No need to fear, Faustina. This is no alcohol. Go ahead, try it."

Though she honestly wanted to reject the offer, the drink was brought to her lips before she could protest. It smelled wonderful, so unlike everything she'd ever tried. She allowed herself a sip, then a gulp, then the whole thing. After that, she swore off the stuff, until he poured her another glass.

"Good, isn't it?"

"Yes."

"Then you'll have it every night!"

She couldn't stifle a smile at this point. It wasn't just good stuff, it was great. The food was excellent, too. What luck to find someone with such refined taste! She could get used to this. Tina craved more than just the banquet, however. She couldn't place her finger on the other need.

"I prefer a short walk around the grounds after dinner. If you'd care to join me..."

There wasn't even a question about it.
155321112112.title: The Feast of the Damned

1553211121121.content:
It was an expansive lot, that was for sure. Tina glanced over the vast blooming fields without a care. Satiated from her hunger, now she struggled with a yearning for something else... Something she couldn't quite figure out and something that inflamed as Wylie stepped closer to her. He trotted her about the gardens without much purpose, or so it seemed. For every so often, he'd pick a lovely little flower and adorn her with it. Tina enjoyed the aroma; it invigorated her. But still, that desire for something or other pervaded her thoughts.

By now, Tina wore a crown of flowers. Wylie, impressed with his work, finally stopped at a nice stone bench. Tina took a seat right next to him. Her heart thumped with anxiety. Wylie continued his examination of Tina silently.

First, he undid her tidy ponytail, letting her hair spill out over her shoulders. He ran his fingers through her hair, each time a little longer in duration. Then, his focus drifted to her hands, which he nonchalantly viewed while holding them. His hands slipped from hers and disappeared for a moment, after which she found them wrapped around her waist. They drifted up her back again and gently brushed up against her shoulder blades. The spot tingled under stimulation. Wylie began to pull her closer, his eyes focused directly on her face now. She tried to look away to avoid embarrassment, but it was for naught. Tina opened her mouth to speak, which only drew him nearer.

"Wylie, I--"

"Have I told you how wonderful you are to me, Faustina?"

Tina blushed like a rose at his soft-spoken statement. She didn't know what to expect from Wylie. Tina had never known many guys, and never romantically. Was that what she wanted? A small voice chimed away in the back of her head, begging her to continue. Tina made her own move closer to him. But Wylie's face dropped the passion from before.

"You're such a fragile bloom, I'd hate to push too far."

He withdrew a bit, triggering Tina to whip her arms around him, too. Wylie snapped back.

"You did promise me anything my heart desires..."

"Ah, so I did."

Temptation crept into Tina's mind, which put a name to the feeling she'd been victim to ever since the first night on the cliffs. She was tempted by what Wylie had to offer her, and she longed for more than just that.

"There's no turning back, Faustina. If we do this, I'll make you mine."

He teased her, and she played along. Tina's arms coiled around Wylie's neck, and the moment awaited. At long last, he indulged her the first kiss she so desired. Their lips pressed together, their arms impossibly locked around each other, their embrace sealing the passion of the night in one fell swoop. Wylie wanted to pull away first, but Tina wouldn't let him. She forged on, until at long last he had to push her away. The awkward pause that ensued after that terminated the mood of the evening. Wylie looked positively drained.

The drive home drifted by without much incident. Wylie didn't speak at all until they reached her doorstep. Tina reached out for him, hoping to score her second kiss, but he was cold to her. She straightened herself up and didn't react to it. If he didn't want to kiss her again, then she wouldn't disobey him.

"Good night, Faustina, we'll continue our work tomorrow."
1553211121121.title: The Garden of Evil

15532111211211.content:
A glistening morning sunrise. Scintillating beams showered Tina's humble bedroom with bright light. Tina awoke reluctantly, so used to the darkness in Wylie's abode. She sluggishly crept out of the covers, wiped her eyes, then meandered towards the bathroom to wash her face. Like every day, she stepped onto her little footstool to reach the sink; she'd always been rather short. As she did so, she couldn't help but notice a strange draft in the room. Had she left a window open last night? Tina turned over her shoulder to check; no sign of tampering at her window frame. Her eyes drifted back towards the bathroom mirror, and only then did she realize how different her perspective was today. Whereas normally her head just barely entered the bottom edge when she stepped up, today she was barely in it from the top.

Tina backed down quickly to get a better look at herself. Her reflection was now centered in the glass, so she'd grown at least a foot overnight! This unsettling discovery led to another, as Tina lowered her hands from the sink to her sides. Her arms brushed across the hem of her skirt! Sure enough, her pretty little nightgown barely resembled a camisole at its current length. Tina coyly tried to pull it down, only meeting great resistance. As she furiously tugged at her tiny gown, she accidentally turned it into a blouse. Then came revelation number three.

Tina gingerly wrapped up the torn portion of her nightgown and slipped back into her bedroom. After locking every conceivable entrance, she slid out of her pajamas and set about getting dressed for the school day. Obviously, there were a couple of problems to tackle first. And going sixteen years without puberty, Tina was clearly unprepared. She hoped that her mother might have something for this.

"Mom? Mom?! Come quick! I need help!"

But Tina's mother didn't respond. Tina nervously paced around the room, then made a run for it. She bolted through her mother's bedroom, praying she wasn't in there. Tina snuck into her mother's closet discreetly, and desperately searched for what she needed. At long last, she located a decent sized brasserie and struggled to put it on before her mother saw her. It didn't fit in the slightest, but it would work for now. Tina nonchalantly exited the room just as her mother entered, and she wondered why her mother looked so dazed. It's as if she'd walked right through Tina without a second thought. A quick check of the clock reminded Tina to hurry up, and she threw herself into the search for fitting clothing.

All of her old blouses were done for, and the biggest sweaters she had were stretched paper-thin across her frame. She practically emptied her wardrobe before she settled on a thick black button-up which held tight despite the strain. Skirts proved just as problematic as none of them wanted to cover her new frame. She eventually settled for a red pencil skirt, though it kept crawling up her legs. She fought to pull her hair up again, as it seemed to trail down her shoulders no matter what. Her temporary solution tucked it all behind a headband. Tina stood dumbfounded at the complete change in her appearance from head to toe.

Would anyone recognize her? She looked vastly different from before. What had even brought this about? Was it a growth spurt, or was it---

Loud chimes erupted from her alarm clock, reminding her of the burden of school. She threw together her belongings and hoped for the best. Tina would be out of luck if things fell apart. She scurried out the door without a thought to her breakfast.

"Goodbye, Mom, I'm off to school. Sorry about borrowing your, well--- goodbye!"

With that she began the long and difficult walk to the high school, pondering on whether or not her attire would hold up.
15532111211211.title: Unexpected Developments in the Field

choices: POV: Trackers are hired on a hunter's quest for the 'Reiter'.
POV: Reiter learns how to control his unknown invisibility and transformation.
15533.content:
I am The Hidden.

My real name? Unimportant. You'll just forget it anyways. But if you must call me something, call me Reiter. It means Raptor in English. It's what my 'friends' in the orphanage called me in which I was raised. It was the children's way of degrading me. To make me seem by name less than human. Less than what they were...

Names stick. You never lose them. People would always called me 'Reiter' from then on. It was an evil thing to call a young child. But I suppose, people being as petty as they are, will always feel themselves empowered, if they denounce others.

Age? I sincerely do not know. Precisely how old I am is a mystery to myself. My parents had abandoned me in a gutter. I have no birth certificate to show you.

By any sane standard, I've had a cruel and abusive childhood. By law, it was the orphanage's duty to take me in from the starvation of the streets. But the kids there and the Matron would do anything in their power to make my live a misery in order to kick me out. But I was stubborn. I stayed despite the bullying. Despite the beatings of the Matron. The rest of that backwash, piece of #### rathole town in which I lived wasn't any better.

The community had no reservations when it came to make example of me. I survived being stoned no less than 3 times over the period of a decade. In all three times, they had stopped only when they thought I had been dead, because I had been buried so deep beneath rocks and pebbles that I was completely submerged in earth. 3 times the Constable, the only soul to have pity on me, and then only because it was his duty to uphold the law, unearthed me and nursed me back into a semblance of living.

You see: I am an albino. Something considered akin to an abomination. A freak, a monster. Oh was very human back then. I...WAS very human back then...
But of course being human still didn't prevent the hatred against someone like me. I was certainly NOT a sight for sore eyes. My hair was the colour of ashes and my sickly pale translucent skin that of virgin-snow. My lips were purple from malnutrition and my nails fell out. My skin was wrapped tightly against my skeleton, like ducktape applied too firmly on a present, as a result of starvation and hunger. My bony jaws, shoulders and ribs shone from beneath the tatters which I called my clothing.

The most intimidating of all: my eyes. They were pink-red. Something quite natural for albino's; merely something to do with a lack of pigmentation I would later learn. But I was a foolish child. I believed it when people started whispering that they were the eyes of a demon...
They shone like paraffin lamps out of a cabin against my fair pale skin.

One day my tormentors, 3 large bullies, succeeded in cornering me. They had beaten me to a bloody pulp for 10 minutes, and I still hadn't so much as lifted a finger to save myself. I wouldn't have minded if they had killed me then and there. I didn't have much aspirations to live for, other than the next stolen loath of bread...

But then came a little girl; she couldn't have been more than 8 years of age. Her name was Marta...I think(names are meaningless to me). A fellow orphan.
She rushed and stood in from of me, shielding me from my tormentors with her body. It was rather pathetic.
"Stop hurting Reiter!"
The lead bully made his greatest mistake when he swung the led pipe in his hand against her petite face, sending her sprawling.

For some reason that, THAT, sent me over the edge. One could mutilate and torture me for as much as one likes, but for some reason seeing someone else, seeing that little girl abused as I had been, filled me with molten anger.

I felt rejuvenated. Filled with energy. Or maybe it was just adrenaline. I changed. Transformed. Before my own shocked eyes and their own. My nails grew. Out of my fingers and into razor claws. My toes grew into talons, gleaming silver. Out of my back 2 rods shot from the shoulder-blades. These rods lengthened and slendered. They turned into massive batlike wings. Wings which I flapped wildly and amateurishly.

My sight reddened as if someone had held a crimson tinted vizor in front of my face. With the reddening hazy vision it felt as if someone had packed ice all around my skin; goosebumps covered my entire exterior.
I could see myself clearly in the frames of some broken windows in a shop next to me. It was an intimidating sight. The original me was still there. Somewhat. But I had claws sprouting from my hands, talons from my feet, and wings that fluttered from the torn clothing of my back. Other than that, all was the same as before. I stared agape at myself as you could expect.

What I didn't expect, was the bullies's next words: "Where'd he go?!" asked the lead shakily.
What did he mean? I was standing right before the idiot. But they all stared through me, past me.

"Oh man, I don't like this! That demon-freak looked like he was melting the one moment and the next he just disappeared!"
"I say we get out of here! I can't see Reiter anymore."
"Forget it!" said the lead arrogantly. "I'm not leaving till that freak is scrap beneath my boots! Come out little Reiter!"

Then I understood. I was invisible. I waved to attract their attention, but they remained oblivious to me. I was invisible...

"If you don't come out where we can see you, Reiter, I'm going to start beating this brat!" said the lead and held up Marta by her pigtails. She wailed, begging me to save her.

I didn't keep her waiting for long. The first bully was sent hurling across the plaza to smash like a ragdoll through the window.

"Holy- Where'd that come from?!" I answered him by holding him by the front of his collar into the air; there she swung, drunkenly kicking for air. I was surprisingly strong for my small form.
"Help! Help! A ghost!" he shouted feebly in a shrill voice.
"No! Just Reiter!" I answered with venom.

His eyes widened to saucers and his pupils shrunk to pips. I sent him following the same fate as bully #1.
I turned to the lead. He had a knife out and held it against Marta's neck. How quiant.
"I'm warning you demon-freak! Just come closer; I dare you to see what happens! I knew! I knew you were a monster!" he called out uncertainly to the empty plaza, clearly not knowing where I was.

I dared not speak to reveal my presence, my only hope to resolve this for Marta's safety.
I snuck up on the lead from behind, him still cat-calling to me and gripped the knife's edge with my bare hand. It cost me a hole through the palm, but it ensured Marta's safety. I wrenched his hand backwards and pulled Marta from his reach.

The redness faded from my eyes and I felt as if being remolded like candle wax again, the ice-cold sensation left my skin. I saw my claws retract and my wings regress back into me. The lead bully's scowl unmistakably indicated that he saw me now. I wasn't invisible any longer.
He charged at me, but I just broke his nose as easily as one would push in the lid of a paper coffee-cup. He sank to his knees and I kicked him into the dreamworld...

Tiny Marta screamed at me. Sighing, I let her down.
"You...you really are a monster!" she said pointing at me fearfully. I didn't answer; just stood rock stiff. So she ran and I never saw her again.

I inspected myself. All traces of the shocking transformation was gone. I was the normal unhandsome me. Was it something I could control? I didn't waste time figuring it out here, for I was in great danger as it was.
I stole the clothes from the 3 incapacitated bullies; for I would need them in the cold of winter. I could no longer stay here. I was done with this rotten place and its inhabitants; they would only come to stone me the moment they had found out about what I had done. I neither knew nor cared where I was going.

So I walked. Never looking back on the orphanage.

I was going to find out how to replicate that transformation. How do I become invisible again? Could those wings really fly? I would find out somehow. The invisibility intrigued me most. It was a good thing not to be seen, and I would never make myself seen again.

I had a new name for myself: the Hidden.
15533.title: Start of a journey.

choices: Revert back to POV of Reiter as he flees.
155331.content:
"You're a professional WHAT...?!" asked the barman in astonishment.
"A professional monster-hunter. You know - I track and hunt Vampires, werewolves, all that junk." answered Flint, slugging his shot of vodka in one go.

"Are you sure you're not a lunatic? I know some nice asylums near here..." said the barman disbelievingly, serving a new glass to Flint.
"Ha! You're SUCH a comedian. Have your laugh; you're not the first idiot to doubt me. And besides isn't it the wanted-poster that stated the village needed to have a 'monster' killed?"

"What stands on a piece of paper and what is, isn't always the same. This village is good for business, but the inhabitants are...how shall I put it? Superstitious?" replied the barman simply, efficiently cleaning a new cup with a linen cloth.

"Oh, you've got THAT right!" exclaimed Flint, again reading the crusty paper of the wanted-poster he had skied. It was illegal to remove anything from a town-hall notice-board, but Flint never did give a rat's behind for the law.
"I mean COME ON! He's only an albino! I dragged myself into this frozen hell-hole to hunt for this! He's just a regular kid! Some monster! I already hate Kraan. I hate its people too. Bunch sour, snobbish, cussing, dry stargazers! "

The barman leaned over conspirotally: "It's not what the kid is, it's what he did." he whispered to Flint, from whom the fumes of alcohol escaped like steam from a sauna.
"Oh yeah? What he do? Not be rich enough? The people here did everything in their power to make me feel unwelcome."
"Yes, but you're not exactly beautiful, Flint. Try washing for a bit. It'll do wonders."
"There goes my fragile feelings."

The barman continued, ignoring him: "They say the albino kid had broken the major's son's nose. He's not the type of man to cross, and he wants the kid stringed up-"
"Vengeance is so sweet." said Flint, belching. "So the local druglord's little runt got clubbed and now his ego's a bit dented. What a lovely bedtime story."

"Shhhhht! I didn't say he was-!" retorted the barman, eyes anxiously darting around to see if they'd been overheard.
"But he's the one who put up the price on the kid's head, wasn't he? There is only so many ways one can afford to pay that kind of money in these parts. Opium or gun-running." said Flint callously, taking in the interior of the dark, shadowy musky bar.
"Well, yeah...but you didn't hear it from me!" the barman said hurriedly and scurried away.

Flint bended his neck to the side to snap the vertebra back into place and turned in his stool to survey the bar inside more closely this time. Also, embarrassingly, to have something to lean his back against before he fell over from his drunken fervour.

The bar was filled with the scrap of society. Bandits, thieves, lowlifes and each and every form of undesirables. All were armed, scarred and in a mean looking mood.

Flint tsked. This was exactly why he despised Bounty-Hunts. It attracted the worst of the lowest.
Flint preferred contracts. Hitman jobs and assassinations. In the underground world, reliability and trustworthiness was a highly regarded trait for hired guns. If you had the integrity to carry out a contract without cheating, you would never find yourself short of work. For kingpins and billionaires would rather hire men at a greater cost and know they would kill the objective or die trying.
There was a very unique and professional code of conduct and etiquette when it came to a "Killing-contract". Both the employer and employee knew they would get their end of the bargain, because they knew that word of the other's cheating would spread though the underground and they would never be able to engage in a contract again.

But while 'Contracts' were clean, Bounty-Hunts were...messy. Not to mention bloody and violent. This violence rarely come from the hunt itself, but from your competition!
You see the rules were simple: the man/woman who brings the 'target' or proof of the death of the target (usually in the gruesomely ironic form the target's decapitated head for a literal 'head-hunt') to the benefactor, was the one to be paid.

Not, I repeat NOT, the individual who actually did all the work and killed the target! In a 'contract' you are the sole huntsman, but in a bounty-hunt you have to worry about the dangers of competitors who would likely kill you without thought or reason, just to eliminate the competition/opposition. A bounty-hunt is therefore a grueling rat-race; a very deadly one.
The underground had a term "parasites". It referred to bounty-hunter gangs who tailed a professional tracker and waited till he got the job done, then pounched on him and stole his prize right under his nose. Sometimes they even killed the tracker as well for the sports.

And since a Bounty-hunt is open for all, it attracts every rat from sewers of the crime-world looking to make a quick buck. Some really disgusting people. Flint really, REALLY, despise Bounty-hunts!

But the one reason why Flint had made an exception for this Bounty-hunt was that he had heard through word of mouth that this kid, this albino kid had gone invisible. Interesting. Maybe this backwash town wasn't filled with such retarded superstitious folk after all. This 'Reiter' as they called him would make an excellent ...."retrieval". Flint was NOT joining in on this hunt for the money, only the privilege to hunt, to track another true monster.

But first things first. Time to deal with the immediate trouble. 3 jackasses were making a bee-line for him, walking with the intent of obvious malice. They were dressed poorly; hoods covered their faces; they all wore brown leather breeches and woolen cloaks draped across their shoulders; they carried their arms resting on their hips, hands resting on large partially sheeved bayonet knives; it was as if they were trying to shout to the world that they were thieves! The bar silenced and the murmurings quieted down. All could see murder was soon to be. This was gonna be fun...

They stood in a semi-circle around Flint. The leader arrogantly holding his head high and looked Flint up and down as if sumarising whether a school boy was properly dressed for the day. Flint's head swayed slightly to the sides and back, the clear result of intoxication.

"Well, what do we have here?" smirked the thief.
"I think its an amateur!" said a second.
"Drinking on the first night! You should know better before entering a job!" said the third.

"Job? I don knoaw wha ya meaan." slurred Flint.

"Oh there's no need to hide it, my good friend! We know you're a bounty-hunter. It's written all over your face!"
"Ma face?" said Flint holding his cheek as if to feel something there that he had not noticed.

"Yes. And we thought, why don't we get to KNOW each other a little better. Seeing as we'll all be such good comrades very soon!"
"So why not buy us a drink, buddy?" asked the second thief.

"Take a hike, sunshine!" replied Flint, unfearingly.
"Don't you think its unwise to upset your new friends?" queried the 3rd thief with malevolence.

"Take one step forward...and I'll kill you with my cup." said Flint evenly, toasting them with the tin-cup he in his hands.

Events came and went in a blur. Flint's apparent inebriation disappeared completely. The 1st thief ripped out his bayonet with a flash and struck at Flint's belly. Flint stopped the thrust with the tin-cup; the bayonet embedded into the bottom. Wrenching the tin-cup sideways, ripped the knife out of the thief's hands and breaking several fingers in the force, making him yelp in pain. But Flint wasn't done yet: he scraped the top rim of the tin-cup against the cement of the table underside in one quick motion, which sharpened the edges drastically, and shoved the cup top-first into the throat of the thief to pierce his esophagus. The thief clutched feebly at his destroyed throat in which the make-shift sharpened cup lay embedded and collapsed.

The 2 remaining thieves retaliated and was wasted in quick order. The 2nd, learning from the 1st thief's mistake, struck sideways, while the 3rd thief struck on the opposite side. Flint, thinking on his feet, grabbed the 2nd thief by the knife-armed wrist and manhandled him as a shield in front of his comrade. The 3rd thief couldn't stop his jab in time, and impaled his friend through the heart. Throwing the 2nd thief aside as if discarding an empty bottle, Flint strode up to the final vagabond, which pulled out a pistol. But he never got to use it as Flint grasped him by the throat and smashed him neck-first into the ground. The sickening bone-crunching snap of his spine could be heard resounding throughout the awestruck silence of the bar.

Flint spat on the dead thieves and strode out of the shadows of the bar. None dared stand in his way or look him in the eye.

He jumped on his snow sledge-bike and burned the throttle. After he was certain the engine was heated sufficiently in this frozen cold he hit the afterburner and was off, mowing through the thick snow.
Flint always was in a good mood when he cleaned up the garbage of the earth.

He studied the map of his GPS and Pathfinder. His bet: the Reiter would hike the shortest route to the next village in this godforsaken cold. Flint would intercept him in no time. The only problem was that every other Bounty-Hunter would figure that out pretty soon as well. Those 3 morons he had just wasted had been hired by a quick tip off to slow him down. There wasn't a moment to lose.

Flint swore that he would get this albino kid first, regardless of whether he was a monster or not. He grinned as the excitement of the Great Hunt pumped through his vanes and the cold wind of the winter blowed over his scarfed face...
155331.title: The Great Hunt.

choices: Reiter is caught up by a gang of bounty-hunters.
1553312.content:
"WHAT THE F###?!" I had raged at the desolate wastes of the steppes when I had seem myself the first time after a complete transformation.

Up until that point I had only been able to grow the wings and retract the claws and talons from my hands and feet.
I had felt my face go green in sickly disgust at my reflection in the mirror-like frozen pond. I wasn't revolted at myself because I looked ugly or hideous. In fact...sort of, I had appeared the opposite. But...this just disturbed me more and I had negated my transformation immediately out of shock.

=====

It had been 3 days since I had left my village of Kraan. The terrible November storms had swept over the Russian steppe, driving great blankets of snow before them. Mother winter, Red October, had arrived in all its might and majesty! It was too cold to sleep, so I had trudged trough ankle-deep powdered ice. The night sky had almost been as bright and as luminescent as day, since the light of the full-moon had reflected off the shining ice of lakes and ravines and off the white snow on the ground. I could see clearly before me as I had walked, and in fact could have read a newspaper in the reflections of the frosted earth.

Frostbite chewed at my extremities (my fingers were blue, my toes grey-purple); and the persistent pestering wind bit at my exposed neck and face ( You must understand the the winds of the motherland, comrade, to understand this phrase. The cold of subzero temperature winds on your bare flesh is so hurtful, that it literally feels like getting bitten before you can cover yourself up with cloth; hence the phrase: "Biting wind.")

I had not been prepared for this endeavor, this journey. True I didn't have much of a choice but to flee before the angry townsfolk, but still...I was ill equipped to survive for long. I had no proper winter-equipment or clothing. Only my rags and the clothes I had stolen from the 3 bullies. I was wrapped up beneath 10 sets of shirts and jackets, but they were worthless. I had pulled 6 pairs of socks over one another, before slipping them in my boots next to a handful of straw I had found in a nearby barn. An old cossack trick: to put woody material between your feet and solid earth. Straws were a poor conveyor of cold, just like rubber was a poor conveyor of electricity.

I had no furs with me either, so I had found torn pieces of books and papers and had wadded them into my pockets and sides to fluff myself up as optimally as possible. The more separation between your insides and the exterior to the cold, the more likely the wetness of the falling snowflakes would penetrate all the way to your skin; because then the true freezing starts, let me tell you comrades! It was minus fifteen Celsius. A deathly temperature. But it was aggravated twofold by the blizzard gales and winds.
This was one of the most hostile environments of earth!

But yet I still stubbornly walked, or perhaps waddled and trudged, sometimes crawling forward. I refused to die just yet. Perhaps it was hardheadedness which had given me the energy to defy mother-nature, as my very eyebrows were sometimes covered with crystallite icicles.
Sometimes the weather was calm. Then there would be grey-blue clouds hanging across the heavens and you could hear the wolves howl in the piercing silence.

I had one thing to keep me from boredom. And trust me, boredom is deadly. It drives you insane in the frozen isolation!
It was the transformation. I had an entire journey to myself to try and figure out how to replicate the morphing. Perhaps it was stupid of me, but I had REALLY wanted those giant batwings; maybe I could fly, then escape this frozen deathtrap...

So like a first-timer on his new bicycle, I had attempted to transform again, all the while I walked. I no idea what to do...and...for the 1st day I had produced no useful results. I just grunted and tried to concentrate like an imbecile as if that would have helped.

By the second day I changed tactics; I tried to remember what I had done since the earlier transformation. At first I thought it was because I had been angered, that rage triggered the transformation; so I thought outraged and hateful things, but that had proved fruitless as well. By the afternoon...I had found the key...

It wasn't anger. It was calm. When the lead bully had harmed Marta, I had never felt so sure about helping someone besides my selfish self. I had been certain, completely calm about what I had to do then.
So instead I thought tranquil thoughts and the gentle slow falling snows aided my mindset.

Like bursting a balloon, my talons and claws snapped from my appendages and my wings had shot out of my shoulder-blades. I had been so ecstatically cheering in glee at success that I would fail to notice, to my later vehement colourful-cursing, that I had ripped my clothes apart in the transformation. Throughout the remainder of the day I had practiced initiating and cancelling my morphing till I could perfect it and recall it at will. However I never seemed to be able to activate my invisibility anymore. But I was satisfied for the day and slept in an abandoned barn, in which I replaced my lost straws and resowed my torn gloves, boots(stolen) and jackets.

By the 3rd day I had suspected that the claws and wings were only a partial transformation. That the rest of my body could change as well. I thought this because sometimes the skin on my hands would darken a shade only to the fingers and at other times would darken all the way to my palms.

So I spent the 3rd day walking, freezing to death, and continuing my controlled transformations and negations. Finally, without warning, I had felt hot all over. Not just in my extremities and back, as previously. Like my flesh and insides were candle wax being remolded by a sculptor. I knew it had been a complete shift this time, so I had rushed over to the nearest frozen water medium, a tiny pond; my excitement bubbling.

It...was not what I had expected. I don't know what precisely I had anticipated I would look like before that moment. But it most certainly wasn't...THIS! I was more embarrassed than horrified at what I saw and just reverted to my normal form before I could see any further...

I was alerted into readiness by the barking of dogs. 4 sets of slays swept past from where I hid in a gully. This was but the 7th time an armed and organised group had passed me in the last 3 days. I grinned to myself. Obviously the inhabitants of Kraan wanted me dead badly. These people were most likely bounty-hunters after my hide.
But I hadn't been a fool; I had hiked several detours to confuse any followers and had avoided the nearest villages and civilized structures, for I knew they would have waited me in there.

I knew these parts of the steppes. And I knew how to track and how to lose trackers on them. I wasn't about to be caught by some retard amateurs. I could easily blend into the snow and camouflage myself with my pale albino skin.
Now if only I could discover how to access my invisibility at will. Then I would truly be Hidden....

====

Flint was having fun. No seriously, he was having the time of his life! This had been one of the greatest hunts in his career! He had clearly underestimated that blistering albino kid! He had stuff to him. He wasn't stupid to be sure. For the kid had avoided every single major road and social center in this district. It was like he had disappeared from the face of the earth. Many bounty-hunters had already handed in the towel, saying that no one could survive in the frosted doom of such a blizzard.

But Flint knew better. He had come across zig-zagging tracks several times and would have successfully caught up, if the snowfall hadn't covered up the damn things! This kid was street-smart, and he knew exactly where he was heading. Flint could see this as the tracks led in a random, but relatively co-ordinated direction and didn't just divert spontaneously like someone lost.

Excellent. This was where the sports truly started! Flint rewrapped his scarf around his neck and reared up his sledge-bike as if in a wheelie, then lanced off into the white wilderness...
1553312.title: Winter.

15533121.content:
I was still searching for a more permanent shelter, distracted by the odd new warmth I had suddenly acquired from exploring my, shall we say, secondary form. At first, I thought the bat like wings, claws, and talons made me a monster but then I remembered seeing similar images in stone statues. What were they called... gargoyles. Yes, gargoyles, the stone guardians who chase evil spirits from the buildings and homes they rest upon. It might be who I am becoming, it might not be. It was just a guess, something to occupy my mind and keep out the madness of boredom.

Another storms was approaching from the north, I could see the low hanging clouds, heavy with snow and I could feel the wind kicking up as if to announce its arrival. Oddly, I did not seem to care as much as the frost bite was gone and the deadly cold seemed almost warm and welcoming, as if I were born to live within it. "How strange this seems." muttering to myself, I said. "When I first started out on my own, I was freezing, starving, gasping for breath..." a small smile formed upon my face. "Only when I embraced the thought of death did the warmth come, I wonder..."

My thoughts were interrupted by the snowy ground giving way underneath me. The hole I had made was too small to allow my wings to spread so to avoid falling in and I tumbled several feet into what looked like an underground cave. I picked myself up and looked around to find, to my surprise, an old church standing in the center of the cave! "There is something you don't see every day." whispering, I said.

Curiosity got the best of me and I approached the church to see the front door open. There, standing in the doorway was a tall, elderly woman. "Welcome, Reiter." with an odd smile, she said. "I have been expecting you..."

With that, bat like wings exploded from her back as claws grew from her finger tips and talons grew from her feet. I gaped at her, especially when I transformed in turn. "Who are you!?" whispering, I demanded.

The woman smiled sadly. "I.. am your mother."
15533121.title: Reiter walks into a trap.

155331211.content:
I turned to walk away only to find the woman standing in front of me, with a patient smile. I looked at her with only my curiosity holding back my annoyance. She was a head taller than myself, her skin the color of polished marble, with mid-back length raven hair and piercing green eyes that remained fixed upon my own. Her wings were folded down and in, clasped at the small talons at the end as if to show lack of aggression. Looking at her, she seemed fairly attractive but I had my doubts that she was truly my mother.

"My name is Chertovka, it means she-devil, though I am far from being one." calmly, the woman said. "You were given the name Daemon, Latin for demon, so Reiter fits as well; though I know that is far from the truth as well."

"If you are my mother, why did you abandon me!?" snapping at the woman, I demanded. "Do you have any idea the hell I went through growing up!"

"You were not abandoned, you were stolen." firmly, the woman replied. "You father, Monstrum, died searching for you." a single tear rolled down her face. "If I had known where you were, I would have come for you."

"You said you were expecting me, how?" my face softening, I asked. "I planned my journey carefully, avoiding any town so not to be captured or killed! I had no plans to fall down that hole!"

"The instant you transformed, I knew you were still alive and I desperately wanted to come for you." daring a step closer, Chertovka said. "Only, after being without me and your father for so long I feared you would flee from me or tear me asunder in your life long rage." smiling, she added, "As I sensed you getting closer, I knew you were following a forgotten instinct and coming home."

"Who stole me?" tears forming, I asked.

"Bounty hunters." with a hint of icy anger in her voice, Chertovka replied. "One in particular, named Flint. He was paid a handsome price to bring the child of the hidden to his client." sighing, she added, "I can only guess how you got away but you can not escape the truth."

"Which is...?" curious, I asked.

"You are The Hidden, an angel of the night." taking a chance to touch my cheek, Chertovka said. "We are not evil, just well equipped to deal with evil."

"Do you live here?" ignoring Chertovka's touch, for the moment, I asked.

"Yes, I live here." simply, Chertovka replied. "We are honor bound never to fight on holly ground of any kind."

"A safe house." softly, I said.

Chertovka nodded. "Will you please come inside and have a hot drink with me?" as I touched her hand, she asked. "I also have a warm bed you would like, if you wish to stay the night."

"If I decide to stay?" confused, I asked.

Chertovka cried slightly. "I was not there when you needed me the most." sobbing, she replied. "Its not my place to make you stay if you want nothing to do with me." she took my hand into her own. "I'll be happy just to have seen your face, one more time."

I sighed. "I need more proof than just your word and a few facts before I believe you, Chertovka." giving her hand a slight squeeze, I said. "I'll come inside but I want that proof."

"Of course!" now crying happily. "I have all the proof you need inside!"

"Lead the way then." a thin smile forming, I said.

Chertovka led me by the hand into the church and quietly closed the door behind us....
155331211.title: No escape from the truth.

choices: Flint intervenes and causes a firefight between bounty-hunters.
155331212.content:
Well. What do I say? Do I demand proof? Deny her claim? Tell her she's lying? It was rather fairly obvious we were related, if even she wasn't my mother. I didn't exactly meet a great deal of people with sets of leathery bat wings protruding from their backs, identical to my own, in life.
It was clear she was what I was. Even if I didn't know what...

Worse still was that this stranger saw me in my full...transformation. Childish perhaps. But I still don't have the bravery to tell you even now what precise...changes it involved. I'll give you a hint. It didn't make me inhuman at all. But It made me very different from the torso up. I promise you idiots, you'll never guess what I mean. You'll all laugh and laugh hard, I assure you. So I'll let it stand for now.

I studied the woman as intensely as she looked at me. Flawless sleek jetblack hair snaked all the way past her shoulders to the small of her back. She definitely wasn't an albino, but her fair skin was as pale as the powdered snow, almost as pasty bleak as that of a corpse. I could further describe her skin to be like polished marble as it shone in contrast beneath her pitch black hair. Besides the wings and the claws and the talons, she was completely humanoid.

She stood as if waiting, with her hands crossed on top of one another in front of her lower waist, her wings were held tightly inwards as if to project the minimal size in order to show as little hostility as possible. She smiled again at me. It was a forlorn sad smile.

"You...you're my mother?" I ventured mistrustingly, still unsettled at having morphed without intention in her presence.
"Yes." she answered softly and simply.

"And you know my...my name? How can you know my name. I was only called Reiter later in life, later in the orphanage." I said suspiciously.

"I have always known of you, my child."

I eyed her face to seek any hidden guile: "And you expected me?"
"Yes."

Perhaps this was a stupid question, but I was confused at that time: "How...could you expect me?"
"I knew you would seek me out from the moment after your first shift, Reiter. Won't you come inside?" she beckoned to the quaint little church behind her. "It's warm and comfortable in there. I have hot drinks and food and a nice bed. You must be tired and hungry."

I made no move to accept her offer whatsoever; and stood as firm as rock. I didn't trust her as far I could throw her; and right now I didn't know exactly how far that was in light of my transformation.

"You're lying. I never sought anyone. I've been walking a plotted path for the last week. I've been walking where I wanted, and nowhere else. I haven't been seeking anything."
"Yet...here you are, my child." she said soothingly. "Strange that. Very strange indeed. I have not left this cave in over a year. A very peculiar coincidence that you would end up here in all places if you have not been seeking me, don't you agree my child?"

I scowled at her. I didn't like the thought that my fate was out of my hands the least. She couldn't possibly be right. And yet...the last week...while I had chosen my routes across the iced surface of the steppes under the guidance of the night sky stars and constellations...it had always been because of a good feeling at choosing a certain direction and not because of any logistical logic.

I licked my blue lips and breathed, a wasp of smoke escaping my mouth in the subzero cold air.
"And...you really...really are my mother?" I repeated the question.
"Yes, Reiter." she replied a second time without any loss of patience.

"You weren't very motherly." I accused suddenly.
"No. I wasn't." she concurred, bowing her head and pursing her lips.

"Where - were - you!?" I spat at her through clenched teeth. "If you are my mother, then why did you never come get me?!"
"I couldn't." she answered meekly.
"I rotted on the streets!" I shouted at her, my temper rising with my voice. "I slept in the gutters! I ate what the leftover scraps that pet dogs wouldn't touch! I eluded dying by stoning 3 times! I waited for my family to get get me! If you truly are my mother, why did you never come?!!"

She had looked at her feet, all the while through my shouting, playing with her fingers, now biting her lips. Like an ashamed, guilty toddler being berated for having been caught doing something exceptionally naughty. I stopped only when I saw tears streaming down her shallow face and chin, to drop already frozen mid-fall before hitting the frosted cave floor.

Her face came back up: "Please. Reiter. Although today is the first time I've seen your face, you must know that I've always lo-"

Her chest convulsed as purple liquid, like grape wine, exploded from it and onto the floor. Following that immediately, a soul-retching deafening boom resounded and echoed throughout the enclosed hollow interior of the icecave. Both she and I watched in horror and shock as more of the purple liquid, which I now presumed to be her special blood, spread from the bullet-wound around to her tunic.

As she fell to her knees, the man that stood behind her holding the Dragunov-rifle, became visible, like the scenery of a mountainside becoming visible after the felling of a pine.

There were seven of them. They were all dressed like cossacks. With felt caps, mittens and boots; woolen trousers and furry jackets. They advanced on us with blood-lust in their walk and eyes. The other six were armed with Kalashnikovs which were wrapped in white camouflage bandages to prevent naked flesh from being frozen on the metal surfaces.

"Ha Ha HA! Bullseye! Now you we can have a cold one! You owe me 5000 roubles, Yatsi! I got the witch first!" jubilated the one wielding the Dragunov.
"Shuddap Boris, and finish the runt too! And make it clean! I'm already freezing my can off!" said one of the men armed with an AK.

I rushed over to my mother's side, where she gasped for breath. If our reunion had not brought me to an emotional-breakdown then our possible separation certainly did. Her wings flapped feebly beneath her in spasms. But I was given little opportunity for any any words.

"Another 5000 says I can pop its right eyeball..." said Boris and raised his rifle to my head, which was less than 20 yards from where he was standing.

I could see through the telescope that was trained on my petrified face, his eye leering evilly at my helpless form. So this was what it means to stare death literally in the face...
155331212.title: Ensnared.

choices: The fight from the Reiter's POV.
1553312121.content:
Flint held his head behind his sledge-bike's exhaust pipe, quite content at suffocating in the toxic carbon-monoxide fumes emanating from it for the privilege of having a source of warmth near his face.

By now the temperature was deathly out on the cold open russian steppes. Nothing could survive in this frozen hell without synthetic aid. This was the temperatures in which bears froze standing up. This was the temperatures in which iron plumbing pipes would burst open with such vehement force as the water inside them froze and expanded, that it looked as if there were explosives planted within them.

It had gotten to a point where taking a wiz was deadly to a man's manhood; instant cancellation to his future children. In these unholy temperatures a careless rub or scratch of one's ear or nose would see them quite literally breaking off of one's face. Flint had seen more than one man surprised at having his nose suddenly fall onto his lap after a pick...

Flint held his Glonass-tracking PDA with a map of this area in front of him and tried to make out where on the good white earth he was as the blizzard wind flapped the paper in his grip. He pulled his scarf tighter and his trenchcoat firmer. The PDA indicated it was -22 degrees Celcius. He was 13 miles from the nearest village. How the hell the Reiter had kept surviving was beyond Flint. But the proof of the little albino kid's endurance was in the form of footprints that kept on going despite this bloody blizzard's attempt to cover up both the tracts and snuff out the life of the person making them.

Flint had gained an enormous and eternal respect for the kid. He was very clever. He had avoided all main roads, skipped major and obvious settlements, and had thrown Flint and every other Bounty Hunter off of his track multiple dozen times. He had slept in abandoned barns and stole food from where it would not have been missed. This kid was born to survive the winter steppes. He was born to survive the Great Hunt.

Yes, the kid was interesting. His footprints in the soft snow even more so. Flint had seen them.....change...multiple times over, as if the boy had transformed. Normal at one point, then suddenly the feet looked as if they had grown massively elongated toenails, like talons. And alongside these talon-feetprints 2 miniature trenches followed; as if the boy had slid sticks beside him on both sides. This had puzzled Flint - a master tracker - for he had never seen anything like them.

After the second day of the chase he figured it out. They were the marks of wings sliding in the snow! Yes, this boy was certainly not human. His supernatural survival of this frosted storm and the wing alternating transformed tracks made that obvious. The only question remaining was: what type of monster was he?
Flint wasn't a man to go into possible actions unprepared; he liked to know what type of beasts he faced for capture...or killing if need be.

At first Flint thought he had it coined: the boy was an Ice-Demon. THEY had bat-like wings and taloned feet, not to mention inhuman resistance for the cold. In fact they thrived in sub-zero temperatures. They were legendary in these parts of the steppes. The peasantry spoke about them as mythical beings whom protected travelers on the icy roads in winter in exchange for fees.

But there was one problem for this theory. As he sat behind his sledge-bike, Flint plucked out the wanted poster he had skied all the way back in Kraan. No, thought Flint as he looked at the Reiter's face, he doesn't look even the least bit androgynous. He was clearly a boy. Starved and ill treated, but unmistakably male. And there lay the problem. Ice-Demons were all female, they were all women.
Great, so much for being prepared, if he found the boy. Whatever. He'll figure it out on the way.

The high whine of massive propellers alerted Flint to danger. He threw a white camouflage blanket across his sledge-bike and dived into a nearby ditch for cover. 3 military hovercraft (they were basically large rubber dingy's with gargantuan fans mounted on their backsides instead of propellers; they were aquatic vehicles which could run on both water and land by sliding across the earth as the force of winds generated by the powerful fans pushed them at speeds exceeding 30mph) , converted to handle the slippery snows, slid past.

If they had seen Flint, they made no attempt to show so. Flint knew those basterds. They belonged to Boris Jorvaskr's outfit.
Now there were 2 things which Flint loathed most of all: empty vodka bottles and that jerk Boris. He was a mean infamous Bounty Hunter which had killed his fare share of men. In fact there were only 2 kinds of men whom Boris did not have conflict with: those who were dead and those he had never met.

Flint hated Boris with all his being. Even more than the cold right now. In fact: his hatred of Boris Jorvaskr was so intense it thawed the very snow he was lying on right now. Boris had stolen more of Flint's bounty's than Flint cared to count. And in return he had given Flint no less than a dozen scars in payment. A deadlier, crueler, more merciless man than Boris, Flint did not know.

Now things had become personal: Flint would find the Reiter first, not as test of his pride as a professional monster-hunter or tracker; but just to spite Boris. That and the Reiter's survival now depended on Flint finding him first. While Flint prided himself as having one of the "cleanest" bounty records (i.e. he had never killed men when he could capture them alive), Boris prided himself as having killed each and every bounty he had ever encountered. Boris was the deadliest known bounty-hunter in the underworld...

Flint jumped on his sledge-bike and gunned the petrol, almost abusing the clutch, and launched forward with the energy of an inter-continental missile. He would not lose this bounty, the gods hear his oath!!
The wind singed in his ears as he reached optimal velocity. But despite almost breaking his petrol pedal, he couldn't catch up with the hovercraft. They were made for these leg-height snows, his sledge-bikes not.

Worse still than falling behind was the realization that the hovercraft was making a bee-line to somewhere; obviously they knew exactly where they were going. Flint dreaded that they already knew the location of the albino boy and were moving to corner him in.
Dammit! Flint could not lose this rat race already! Not after having come so far after the Reiter already.

Flint's distraction from the road cost him valuable reaction time...
He saw the ravine too late, and swerved to miss it, causing him to fall off of his sledge-bike. Flint went down like a meteor into the hard snow. But it didn't end there. The ice broke beneath him and he tumbled even further: an ice shaft! And he was falling into one of its tunnels!

The tunnel was sloping down almost vertically, and Flint slid down it as if on water-worm amusement slide. Eventually, luckily for Flint, the slope evened out and and he slid to a standstill. Making sure that no bones were broken and no joints detached, Flint sat up slowly and massaged the bumps and sores that covered his entirety. Now that was one hell of a hard fall...

Flint grimaced. He was somewhere underground. Well actually, under-ice. This frozen ice bunker could be kilometers deep. He stood up slowly and started shuffling in pain, but stopped as he heard voices, and lay down on his stomach again.

Flint gasped and whistled softly inwards as he saw his tunnel open into a massive ice-cave. The interior was colossal. A derelict church stood on one side. Some of the surface's sunlight penetrated into this ice-cave, lighting up the vast interior with a pale blue light. 2 people stood facing one another in front of the church. Flint crawled closer to see them more clearly, then grinned!

Bingo! The 2 were monsters! They had bat wings hanging from their backs! One was a beautiful young dark-haired woman, and the other which was a petite albino kid! The Reiter boy! Or wait...it was a boy, wasn't it?
The frail albino child had shoulder length snowy hair and the hint of a youthful bosom on his...or her chest. He or she looked distinctly female. Flint dug out the wanted-poster and looked at the Reiter's face again. What? It looked like the Reiter if he was a girl.
What on earth? Nevermind, he'll figure it out later when he captured-

The distinct booming sound of a Dragunov-rifle going off assaulted Flint's ears as the woman with jetblack hair was shot in the chest from behind. Dammit! screamed Flint in his mind as he saw Boris walking up to the albino kid which held the wounded woman.

Unfastening a flamethrower from his back-sling, Flint jumped down from the ledge he was lying on and curled his finger against his firearm's trigger...
Payback time.
1553312121.title: Chase.

15533121211.content:
Like the Pharoah whom suffered the wrath of God as he tried to chase after Moses into the split sea, so too did Boris see a pyre of fire decended on him and his men as Flint let loose the contents of his flamethrower. Boris was in the process of curling his finger on the Drugonov-rifle's trigger when flames and smoke rained from above. Deciding on survival before killing the Reiter, Boris dived sideways out of the leaping scorching fangs of the oiled fire-spray. 4 of his men weren't so lucky, and was gruesomely turned into flailing wailing human torches.

Having finished sliding down the ice-cave's side from the ledge, Flint jumped up heavily from the ice and let loose a second volley of fire into Boris's men; his grey trenchcoat was illuminated in the fiery light making it shift colour from orange to yellow to red. The man named Yatsi succeeded in letting off a barrage of his Kalashnikov assualt-rifle in Flint's general direction, but was blinded by the intensity of the heat. The shots, however, went close to home: creating sparks of vicious icy shrapnel that went airborne right next to Flint's head, forcing him to crouch-roll behind a massive postbox-sized frozen stalagmite for cover.

Flint could see the Reiter, taking advantage of this miraculous diversion, dragging his mother back into the safety of a ditch which lined the road back to the little church. Good. At least the boy would not be harmed. Which was something Flint couldn't exactly say for himself as Kalashnikov fire raked the ice-stalagmite behind which he hid.

Damn. Boris and his possey had recovered from his surprise attack too quickly. Flint had hoped to do more damage, but he had taken out less than half of the enemy bounty-hunters. Given sufficient time, planning and preparation Flint could wipe out a hundred men. But the Reiter would have died if he had not acted instantly. Now Flint was trapped behind this stalagmite. They would encircle him, corner him, and dispose of him in the next critical few seconds. Dammit.

=========

The blackness of Boris's rifle barrel aimed at my head seemed to be the last sight that would greet me as I left the world. Then out of nowhere, without so much as a warning, the ice burned. It was as if the sun itself had fallen from the sky. I had never thought Ice could burn. It was after all bloody frozen water! But that day the ice burned and the men that tried to kill me burned with it. It wasn't a sight or something to be heard for children.

It was only then that I had realized a third party bounty-hunter had joined in with the fun and had started a literal firefight. Now I was never one to be easily surprised. I only ever reacted. As a result of my upbringing on the dirt of the streets, being surprised when a one-time escape opportunity presented itself whenever sadistic bullies, gangsters or street-bangers had me in a vice was a no go. You had to be quick minded and quick footed to survive the streets. So without stopping to blink, I pulled my mother - something made easy by my enhanced strength in my transformed state - and made for cover.

Fire, smoke, bullets and ice shrapnel filled the cavity of the ice-cave as I made my way through this hellstorm of fighting. It was only as I trudged on that I had realized I was invisible again. My hands were transparent and see-through, like a glass bottle. Strangely enough whatever I was in contact with also seemed to share my invisibility - that included my clothes and my mother which I dragged as she bled her purple blood. It seemed genuine extreme danger triggered the invisibility, but I had no time or mind to figure that out right now.

I laid down my mother, fearing the worst of her wound, but while my face was the embodiment of despair, hers was that of total serenity. She smiled up at me: "Don't fear my dear son. You can't be harmed in here." and she touched my cheek with an ice-cold hand.

Then she said something which made no sense at the time and made me think that she was delusional: "No. Not at the hunters! At the ceiling!" What??

=========

"Flint, you son of a harlot!" raged Boris with a demented voice in the silence of the cease-fire: "I swear I shall dismantle you! We're going to flush you out and hang your stinking corpse for the wolves! Do you hear me?! I'm going to rip your head off and piss down your neck!" Yatsi and the other men began to circle around the stalagmite.

"First you'll have to catch me, you guts-lover!" Flint shouted back.

Flint smiled. This was it. The end of the line. There was no use in hiding his trump card if he died, now was there? He discarded his flamethrower - he wasn't going to need that right now - and nimbly assembled a miniature grenade-launcher from a stock, lock and enormous barrel he carried by the backpack. Time for plan B. Plan Bomb.

Flint was just about to swing out from his sitting position to unleash 10 kilograms of nitro-sychron on Boris, when a distinct female voice in his head whispered: "No. Not at the hunters! At the ceiling!" The heck? What voice was that? Was Flint hallucinating from fatigue? But Flint's eyes were drawn to the roof of the ice-cave. A roof which was populated by scores of very heavy, very sharp, very fragile looking ice-stalactites! Oh hell yeah! Now that was a very sexy target if Flint ever did saw one!

Taking the advice of the voice he pressed the grenade-launcher to his shoulder, aimed 70 degrees upwards, and fired away...

Yatsi and Boris looked upwards to see something akin to a firework lance into the air - a smoke trail following its path. Then it felt and sounded as if hell broke loose and the heavens showered down! The bomb imploded, and the stalactites exploded from the roof raining down a second shower of death. This time one made of ice. Ice in the form of half ton falling razor spikes!

The remainder of Boris and his men was buried beneath an avalanche of ice and dust. Their screams of terror drowned by the earthquake-equivalent noise. Flint grinned. He was always in a good mood when he mopped up the trash of the world...

======

I saw what had happened. Yet I could not believe the sight that had met my eyes. But who could blame me? A new mountain of ice and snow inhabited the center of the ice-cave. My former tormentors buried beneath it.

If I had childishly thought things were over at that point, I was sadly mistaken: for a hand, wielding a Drugonov-rifle ominously burst from the packed heap of ice, like the arm of a zombie emerging from its grave. Boris. He wasn't dead yet.

I could see the newcomer, whom they had called Flint, freeze in his tracks after he had made way for the ice debris heap. Obviously he had expected all the other bounty-hunters to have perished in that fall as well.

"Flint!!! You'll pay for that!! Oh yes, you'll pay!! I'm going to strangle you with your own guts for that!!!" The man named Flint just stood still, almost acceptingly, inviting the inevitable unopposable death that awaited by the hands of Boris and his Drugonov. Chillingly, a reminder of how I had stared death in the face.

I made the decision then and there which of the 2 bounty-hunters I'd rather not have chasing me. I was still invisible, and used that to sneak up on the unsuspecting hunters. It was easy. Like taking bread from a rich baker on the street...

"So how'd you like to die, Flint?!" said Boris, his Drugonov aimed squarely at Flint's chest.

"How?" said Flint, impassively: "In my bed, at the age of 80, with 10 whores and twice that many bottles of vodka."

"Always the comedian. I'm not going to miss your jokes. Bye you-" I smashed a fist of claws into the cossack's felt cap and sent him reeling forward. He collapsed unconscious. Now for the other one...

But dammit! My invisibility chose to wear of right at that vulnerable point. Oh shucks. I stared at the man named Flint and expected him to have a go at me, but to my surprise he just dug out a pipe and lit it. Sucking and puffing the end he then said: "So you're the Reiter. Huh. This is...not what I was expecting."

You jerks are going to laugh. Just laugh, I could care less right now, for I am to tired after that ordeal. Do you remember when I told of my full transformation shocking me so badly? And that you jerks would laugh at when I told what exactly it involved from the waist up? It was more embarrassing than horrifying. The claws, talons and wings were all that indicated I was a monster. The rest? Sigh.
The rest was that of a girl. When I had seen my reflection on a frozen pond the first time, I was puzzled to see an albino girl staring back at me. It peeved me to no end when I had discovered I was the reflection. Long hair, an oval face, a waist, and worst of all: a bosom. And I had to endure all that in silent shame in front of this stranger. Not to mention I had to do so in front of my mother earlier. My full transformation was me as a girl...

"Who are you?" I asked.

"Me?" said Flint. "I don't have time for names, but if you really must call me something: Friends call me Flint. Enemies call me the Pyromancer."

"I'm the Hidden." I said suddenly, before I could stop myself; liking this stranger slightly more. Someone who also didn't put value into true names

"Ooh, you have a title too. Fancy."

"Are you going to hurt me?" I asked tiredly.

Flint looked at me sideways: "I'm not going to do anything to you. You just took down Boris. Something I have failed to do for over 30 years. You're free to walk."

I just stared at him mistrustingly; who is this lunatic? My mother's voice interrupted our bizarre conversation: "Flint? Is that you?"

It seems the universe was far from done when it came to playing pranks on me. There stood my mother, unharmed, untouched; her wound completely vanished.

Flint's pipe fell from his mouth as he gasped: "Chertovka?"
15533121211.title: Fire and Ice.

15533121212.content:
I took the woman who I had started to believe was my real mother and looked at the wound in her chest. To a human, it was clearly fatal and I could not see her breath in the chilled air. My one chance to learn why I was abandoned, why I had to suffer as I did growing up were all taken away by a shot in the back. "Mother.." whimpering, I muttered. "No...."

I wanted to mourn over my loss but the sound of a trigger being pulled reached my ears and I reared my head up to see a bullet firing from a Dragunov-rifle! Instinctively, I swiped at the bullet, not knowing how that would do and was surprised to see two halves of the bullet flying harmlessly by on either side of my head. I had cut the bullet in half with my claws!

"Damn it!" yelled the man with the rifle. "I could I have missed!?" he tried to fire again only the gun jammed. "Shit!"

This was my chance to make the man who murdered my mother pay the price. I did not want to kill him, just leave him with the same chances I had. I gently laid Chertovka down onto the snow then turned to the man before spreading my bat like wings and giving an ear piercing roar. The man jumped, struggling with his rifle but paused as I vanished from sight. "Who is the prey now, you bastard!?" flying towards the man, I thought.

I landed hard in front of the man, making myself visible as I roared and swatted the rifle from his grasp. The man responded by coming at me with a hunting knife, which I was expecting, and countered by using my claws as a blade and engaged him in sword play. "You dare toy with Boris, demon!?" furious, the man screamed.

I did not answer the man as I was moving the fight to his three hover craft. Once there, I slashed at Boris and he dove aside to avoid being gutted by my claws. Only I was not trying to slash him, I drove my claws into the rubber tubing of the hovercraft, creating loud and satisfying pop before air rushed out of the giant tub. "No!" furious, Boris screamed. he then turned to me. "I'll hang your hide on my trophy wall!"

I was about to continue with the fight but a sudden warmth reached my feet and I quickly took to the air as the ice below us and the hovercraft gave way. The three machines fell into the ice cavern, landing onto a frozen underground lake and breaking through into the frozen waters below. I heard the man screaming as they struggled to pull themselves out but hypothermia hits quickly in Siberia and it hits hard; their chances were not good. Boris, to my surprise, managed to escape the fall by driving his knife into the ice and used it to climb back up. Just as he pulled himself to the surface, I grabbed his hand and held him off the ground. Boris slashed at me with his knife but I effortlessly stopped him with a single claw. "You have a choice, Boris." coldly, I said. "Either take those who survived and walk to the nearest village to beg for help and have a chance to live or stay here and fight me, which I guarantee you will die."

With that, I threw Boris away from me before flying up and diving back down to Chertovka. There, to my shock and much relief, I found her alive! She was sitting up smiling at a man who had knelled before her, scowling.

"I did not recognize you at first, you Koschie." annoyed, the man said. "Had I know it was you, I would have taken the first shot myself."

"I have not seen you in sixteen years, Flint." grinning, Chertovka said. "You're still cute when you're angry."

"Mom, you're alive!" landing next to her I exclaimed. I then gave the man, Flint a scowl. "You know this man!?"

Chertovka nodded. "Reiter, I would like you to meet Flint." smiling, she said. "He and my husband, Monstrum fought over me when we were teenagers." she then giggled. "He was angry when he found out I was a 'she demon'."

"What else would you call your self!?" almost scowling, Flint asked.

Chertovka winked at me then replied, "Unique."

I could not help laugh then suddenly turned serious. "You are here to kill us too, aren't you?"

"I was paid and sent out to capture you." sighing, Flint said. "That was before I knew your mother was Chertovka."

"How does that matter?" curious, I asked.

"I promised Monstrum I would not kill you or Chertovka." flatly, Flint replied. "He saved my life a while back and I owed him a debt of honor." he sighed then added, "I took you from your mom because I thought you were born normal, in need of a normal family...."

I saw red and jumped to my feet. "You!" screaming, I said. "You were the one who left me at that hell hole of an orphanage!!"
15533121212.title: The fight from the Reiter's POV.

155332.content: The past writer ended the ability to make characters, so that is what this chapter is for.
