1553322.title: New characters.

1554.content:
Name: Kylie Burke
Age: 18
Eyes: Hazel
Hair: Brown

My name is Kylie Burke, and this is what happened.

I was the oldest of three girls. Sara was 13, and Iris, a bit of a surprise, was 5.

I had graduated two weeks before my birthday. My Journalism studies, along with my time on the school paper, had gotten me accepted into my safety school. All my life, I planned to be a TV reporter when I grew up.

As it turned out, I needed a backup plan, for unexpected reasons.

******************************


I woke up on the morning of my 18th birthday, wondering what would happen today. I had seen a strange car parked in front of the house once, and I wondered if it was for me. It wasn't a flashy car by any means, but it would be good enough for a first car.

As I got dressed, I noticed my clothes seemed a little looser. I wasn't on a diet, and there were no recent changes in my exercise routine, so I wondered why. I hoped it wasn't serious: I had my whole summer, my whole life, ahead of me.

Looking around, my eyes fell on my growth chart on the door frame, the pencil markings showing how much I'd grown over the years. The last, tallest mark was when I had stopped growing. On a whim, I stood against the door frame, held my hand at the top of my head, and looked.

"That can't be right."

I triple-checked that my feet were together and flat on the floor, my knees straight, my back straight. I marked my height with a pencil. Then I looked.

"That's impossible."

Finding a tape measure, I checked to see if all the marks were right. It seemed unlikely that anyone would alter the marks just to play a prank on me, on the off chance I would decide to measure myself, but not compared to the alternative.

The upper mark, from when I was fourteen and a half, was 5', 8", the same as I had been since.

The mark I'd just made was 5', 7".

I had somehow become an inch shorter.
1554.title: Kylie Burke

15541.content:
So now that I had established that I was shorter, there was the question of what I could do about it. People aren't supposed to get smaller, but I did.

"Kylie, honey," Mom called up the stairs. "Breakfast is ready."

"Can you come up here, Mom?"

Mom came up. "What is it?"

"I'm shorter."

"What are you talking about, young lady? Teenagers don't get shorter."

"I'm serious, Mom. Look." I showed her the marks, and stood under the one I'd made.

Mom then took the tape measure and checked the marks for herself. "But that's impossible!"

"Apparently not," I said. "What could cause this?"

"I have no idea, Kylie. I've never heard of something like this before. Your party isn't until 3:00. We can get you to the doctor, and maybe find out more about this."

Seeing the doctor certainly wasn't how I wanted to start my birthday, but there was no other way to figure this thing out.

******************************


"What seems to be the problem, Kylie?" the nurse asked.

"I've somehow gotten shorter."

"Shorter?"

"I've been five-eight for years, but I woke up this morning, and I was just five-seven."

The nurse looked skeptical, but she measured me and checked my chart. Her eyes widened, and she left the examination room.
15541.title: Ask for Help

155411.content:
My family physician, Dr. Penny Bowman walked in looked perplexed. "Well, this is a new case for the record books." Frowning, she said. "Our records did show that you were five- eight but, upon measuring you..." She winced. "You are now five- five."

"I shrank even more..." Turning pale, I demanded.

looking at my clothing confirmed it, they were more loose than ever and I began to tear up as I looked at Penny, my eyes pleading. "What is causing this?"

Penny sighed. "I don't know..." Softly, she replied. "Nothing like this has ever been recorded in medical history."

I began to cry as mom tried to comfort me. "Is there anything you can do, doctor?" Worried, she demanded. "Something to stop this shrinking?"

Penny sadly shook her head. "Not without knowing what had caused it, no." Serious, she replied. "I will have to order some tests and try to find an underlining cause..."

"But... It's my birthday..." Crying, I pleaded.

"At the rate you are shrinking, you may end up celebrating it the size of a newborn." To my further tears, Penny countered. "We need to get to the bottom of this and fast."

Albeit reluctantly, I nodded. "I'll call your friends and let them know you are in the hospital." Softly, mom said. "All they need to know is that you are sick."

Again, I reluctantly nodded and mom walked off, retrieving her cellphone. "What a way to celebrate my birthday..." Pouting, I said.

"Well, on the bright side, you will go down in medical history." Trying to be light, Penny said only it only made me pout more.

"Did you have to say 'going down'...?"

Penny winced. "Sorry."
155411.title: I'm Even Smaller

1554112.content:
"Fascinating," Dr. Penny said. "Your shrinking is occurring at the cellular level. We can actually watch your cells dwindling under the microscope."

"Sounds amazing," I said. "Are we any closer to fixing this? I don't need a microscope to tell I'm shrinking." I hopped down from the examination table, and my pants and panties pooled around my ankles.

"I wish I had better news on that front, Kylie. Unfortunately, we haven't found any foreign substances in your blood. There's nothing in your system that shouldn't be there. You're perfectly healthy, except for the fact that you're shrinking."

"What do we do now, Doctor?" Mom asked.

"I'd like to bring in some specialists."

"Do we have to?" I asked. "I've been poked and prodded enough. I'd rather not have too many people knowing what's happening to me."

"Well, it's up to you, Kylie. I can attempt to conduct private research, see if there are even any rumors of a case like yours."

"How small am I now?"

Dr. Penny measured me. "Five feet, one and a half inches."

I sighed. It wouldn't be long before I was smaller than Sara. Then smaller than Iris. Then smaller than Iris's dolls. Then... I decided to get off that train of thought.

Mom didn't say anything as we drove home, leaving me alone with my thoughts, and my shrinking body.
1554112.title: After the tests.

15541121.content:
"What did the doctor say?" Dad asked when we got home.

"According to the tests," Mom replied, "Kylie's the picture of health. There's nothing inside her that's causing this. Dr. Penny wanted to bring in specialists, but Kylie said no."

"I suppose I can't blame her," Dad said. "At this rate, there's not much they could tell us before... "

"I'm right here," I said.

Sara grabbed me. "Come on," she said, "let's see what I've got that you can wear."

Once we were upstairs, and behind Sara's bedroom door, she said, "I bet you forgot what it was like when they did that. It's like there's a big sign somewhere: 'You Must Be THIS Big To Have Us Pay Attention To You.'"

"At least you know it'll get better for you," I said, taking off what clothes I hadn't shrunk small enough to fall out of yet.

"Do I? From what Mom said, they don't know why you're shrinking. And, if they don't know why you're shrinking, they can't tell if Iris or I will find ourselves shrinking." She threw some dresses on the bed. "I figure, one-piece outfits that go over the shoulder should stay on you longer. Take a look."

Sara always was the smart one. I picked a dress and put it on. It was a little snug, but I knew that would change quickly. "Good enough, sis. I hope your 18th birthday goes better than mine."

"Way to set the bar low, sis."

"For you, it's low," I said, opening the door. "For me, I don't know how much longer I'll be able to clear it."

As we walked out, I heard voices, telling me that the moment I'd feared had arrived. "You can't see her!" Mom said. "She's sick!"

"She's my girlfriend, Mrs. Burke," replied Todd Warner.

"And she's my best friend," added his sister, Jillian. "If she's sick, it's our job to make her feel better."

All the talking stopped when we got to the landing, and everybody could see what was happening to me. I was still taller than Sara, but not by much.

"Hi," I said.
15541121.title: At Home

155411211.content:
Todd and Jillian had a million questions. Unfortunately, I didn't have many answers. About the only thing I could tell them was that I wasn't in any pain. Shrinking felt the same as not shrinking. By the time I had explained everything to the best of my ability, Sara was taller than I was.

My 18th birthday party wasn't like anyone else's. All the presents were now too big for me, or soon would be, in the case of the car. We had some fun, but the main activity was watching the guest of honor getting smaller. When it came time for cake and ice cream, I didn't have much of an appetite, probably because of my shrinking stomach.

Dr. Penny had overestimated how much I would shrink, though. I was 4 feet tall, which was bad enough, but bigger than a baby.

After the party, Iris took me to her room, where I picked a dress from her wardrobe.
155411211.title: A Most Unusual Birthday Party

1554112111.content:
My phone rang that afternoon. "Is this you, Kylie?" Dr. Penny asked.

"Yes, Doctor," I said. "I have you on speaker phone, it's easier for me."

"You're probably wondering why I'm calling."

"Have you found something?" I started to feel something like hope.

"Just speculation. Have you ever heard of the Native American Deetkatoo?"

"No, Doctor."

"The Hawaiian Menehune?"

"No, Doctor."

"The Norwegian nisser, or the Swedish tomtar?"

"No, Doctor." What was the point of this?

"Leprechauns, gnomes, hobgoblins?"

"Doctor," Dad asked, "are you talking about fairies?"

"Technically, I'm talking about little people. There are legends of tiny humanoid beings in every culture on Earth. And every legend has a basis in fact."

"Doctor," I asked, "are you saying that... I'm becoming one of the little people?"

"It's just speculation, Kylie. But it's all we've got to work with."

******************************


That night, I was wearing a T-shirt as a sleep shirt. At 3 feet tall, it covered me pretty well.

Mom came in. "How are you doing, pumpkin?"

"Pumpkin? You haven't called me that since I was... since I was a kid."

Mom hugged me. "I'm sorry, Kylie."

She had picked up on what I meant. I had almost said You haven't called me that since I was little.

And that was the problem: I was little. And getting littler.
1554112111.title: A Solution to the Mystery?

choices: My Family Begins to Frighten Me
15541121111.content:
I woke up the next morning, and noticed two things: I had shrunk more overnight, and my bedroom door was open. "Hello?" I called out.

Mom came in. "Good morning, Kylie. How'd you sleep?"

"I had some weird dreams. Dogs and cats thought I was a treat. You guys thought I was a bug. I think I fell between atoms at one point. And there was one where a little person came in here. She looked at me, and said it wouldn't be long now."

"What wouldn't be long?"

"I don't know, she left through a hole in the wall before I could say anything." I looked over the edge of the bed. "Little help?"

Mom helped me out of bed, and I went to the door frame. Mom measured me. "What's the damage?" I asked.

"You're two feet tall."

I had shrunk almost four feet in 24 hours. "Maybe that's what she meant. At this rate, I don't have much longer before this stops, one way or the other."

******************************


Mom and Dad had been busy after I had gone upstairs. Mom did some tailoring on one of Iris's onesies, and Dad had dug out Iris's high chair. No prizes for guessing who got to use them as we sat down to breakfast.

Later, Iris invited me to a tea party with her favorite doll, Nikki Fleming. Nikki was one of those dolls who had a backstory involving American history and social class, as well as a whole bunch of outfits. "Would you like to wear one of Nikki's dresses, Kylie?"

I compared Nikki's dress to the onesie I was wearing. "May I?"

Iris turned to Nikki. "My big sister, Kylie, wants to borrow your dress. Is that okay?"

Apparently, Nikki agreed, because Iris presented me with some of the nicer dresses in Nikki's wardrobe. I chose a blue skirt, since it would be much longer on me in a few hours.
15541121111.title: 2 Feet Tall

choices: A Message from the Little People
155411211111.content:
As I inched closer to being only 1 foot tall, I noticed that I was starting to feel differently in the presence of my big family. I still loved them, and I knew they loved me; but, the smaller I got, the more afraid I became of them.

"Why so nervous, Kylie?" Mom asked, after seeing me flinch once too often.

"Why do you think?" I replied. "I am surrounded by giants. I'm not invulnerable. I bleed. My bones break. And, the more I shrink, the more likely it is that you could hurt me badly. Every sudden movement, every enormous face in mine, just reminds me of how dangerous to me this whole situation is."

"Kylie, surely you don't really believe that any of us would ever do anything to hurt you?"

"Does the phrase 'I didn't mean it' conjure up any special images in your minds? We were capable of hurting each other accidentally when we were all normal size. Think how much more capable you are of accidentally hurting me now.

"And, even if you don't hurt me, you can't help being intimidating as hell. And that doesn't go away when you stick your billboard-sized face right in mine."

"Alright," Mom said. "We'll move more carefully around you, and we'll avoid getting our faces too close to yours. We don't want to do anything that would make you uncomfortable. Is that better?"

"God, this brings back memories."

We all turned at the unfamiliar voice.

In the room with us was a woman, about Mom's age, but around six inches tall. She was dressed in scraps of cloth, and she had a stick which she used as a cane.

"You're the little person I saw last night," I said. "It wasn't a dream. You're real."

"I am, indeed. My name is Marty. I am from the Little People. I am here to tell you all that, very soon, it will be time for Kylie to leave you and take her place with us."
155411211111.title: My Family Begins to Frighten Me

1554112111111.content:
"Marty," I said, "you said this brought back memories. Did you shrink, too?"

She nodded, and said, "I did," for the benefit of those who couldn't see the gesture. "I had just come back from my honeymoon, and my rings fell off my finger. It was terrifying, as you can attest. I was helped near the end, and now I'm paying it forward, just as you will someday, Kylie."

"How did you know I was shrinking?"

"It's hard to explain. We just seem to sense it. Then we set things up, and we send someone to watch, and to let those involved know."

Sara spoke next. "Will Iris and I shrink?"

"Unlikely. It happens to random people. The only consistency is that it happens to people between the ages of 18 and 38."

"Lucky me, I got it on my birthday."

"Excuse me," Mom said, "but we're all forgetting something. You said it was your plan to take our daughter away from us. Do you really expect me to be okay with that?"

"I hope you will," Marty said, "for Kylie's sake. You're only going to become more dangerous to her." She held up her cane. "I didn't always need this. My first husband was sure that he could take care of me, and keep me safe. He believed that right up until he gripped me just a little too hard. I want to spare Kylie that. Do you?"

Mom shut her eyes at that. I could tell she was picturing accidentally doing that to me.

"Give us some time," Dad said. "Time to say goodbye."

"I can give you until Kylie is seven inches tall. After that, she comes with me." With that, Marty slipped away from us.
1554112111111.title: A Message from the Little People

15541121111111.content:
Mom and Dad called Todd and Jillian, to tell them what was happening. By the time they got to the house, I was down to 11 inches. Barbie's clothes were too rough on my sensitive skin, so Mom cut up one of Dad's silk handkerchiefs and made a couple of dresses for me. We sat around talking, reminiscing about our favorite experiences together, trying to ignore how the hem was steadily creeping down my legs.

When I had shrunk to 8 inches, Mom switched me to a smaller dress, and we all knew that time was also growing short. "I'm going to miss you oh so much, Kylie," Jillian said.

"Same here, girlfriend," I replied.

Todd was next. "I'll never forget you, Kylie."

"You'd better not. I put too much work into making you the perfect boyfriend. Have a good life."

Sara and Iris couldn't stop crying. "It's okay, guys," I told them. "I'm not dying, I'm just going somewhere else. Maybe I can come back here sometime, like on my birthday. If I can, I'll be here, and you can tell me all about what you've done."

Mom and Dad knelt down. "Do you think you can take a couple of giant faces close up?"

"I can try."

They both kissed me.

As they set me down, I heard a small cane clicking on the hardwood floor. "I think it's almost time."

"That it is," Marty said. "Ready?"

"If there is such a thing. Will I be able to visit?"

"Most of us prefer to treat it like a Band-Aid. But I suppose that the occasional visit can be arranged."

I followed Marty, then turned to wave goodbye. "I'll see you again. I promise."

Marty opened up a hidden hole in the wall, and we left the world of big people behind.
15541121111111.title: Saying Goodbye

155411211111111.content:
"So," I asked Marty, "what's it like where we're going?" She led me to a staircase, which was illuminated with Christmas lights.

"It'll take some adjusting on your part," she replied as we descended. "It always does. But I promise you, you will come to love our world. What was plain among the big people will appear wondrous to you now. If your soul craves adventure, you can find it wherever you look. The necessities are not things to be earned among us, but come easily, and are freely given."

I couldn't tell how far down we were actually going, but it seemed to me that we went a long way. Finally, we reached an archway, and we went through.

I had no expectations about what I would see, but I was still awestruck.

The way up to my former home let out onto a space that seemed to me the size of a grand concourse. The whole thing was lit by Christmas lights. Where a statue might have stood in the world above, an old G.I. Joe stood. A Barbie stood at the opposite end. People went this way and that, looking not like people downtown going to work, but like children at the State Fair, taking in the spectacle around them.

Somebody spotted us and shouted "Newcomer!" As more people saw me, the chorus of "Newcomer!" grew, mixed with cries of "Welcome!" Those closest to me would embrace me, or kiss me, or just hold my hand.

I wept tears of joy. After two days of shrinking, here was a place where I finally fit. Everything looked and felt right.

Even finding that I was no longer 7 inches tall, but a fraction under 6 inches, didn't bother me. My size didn't separate me from people anymore, it united me with them.

I was home.
155411211111111.title: A Whole New World

1554112111111112.content:
"Welcome, newcomer to In-walls." Kindly, a young woman said. "I am Quinn Muse, this month's mayor."

"There is a new mayor elected every month?" Surprised, I asked.

Quinn giggled. "It's just a figurehead role." Bemused, she replied. "Everyone has their turn to be mayor." She motioned to me. "Please, introduce yourself."

"Um... my name is Kylie Burke." Smiling, I said. "I have so many questions..."

Quinn smiled. "Then ask." Simply, she said. "We are an open minded people."

I took a breath, trying to choose my words carefully. "What is expected of me here?"

Those around me laughed, which confused me. "Nothing is expected of any newcomer to our community, Kylie." Bemused, a young man replied. "I am Travis Minuscule, one of the brave scouts and gatherers."

"Scouts and gatherers?" Curious, I asked.

"We borrow everything we need from the normal world." Calmly, Travis explained. "Nothing is taken that they need day to day but things that can easily be replaced by them if they were ever lost."

"I'm sure you remember losing a sock here or there." Smiling, Quinn said. "Or finding you have a little less cold cereal than you thought you did."

After a thought, I smiled as it all began to make more sense. I turned to Travis. "Is your job dangerous?"

"It has its risks." Shrugging, Travis said. "Still, I love adventure... I live for the chance to collect something new for the community."

"When I am not mayor, I serve as a weaver." Kindly, Quinn said. "I help several others make clothing for the community." She motioned to a small young girl in the crowd, no taller than a single inch. "Maria Speck is our youngest community member at the age of twelve."

"Pleased to meet you, Kylie." Giving a courtesy, Maria said. "I am the telegrapher of the community."

"You have a telegraph?" Surprised, I asked.

"It is how we communicate with the other villages in the area and beyond." Simply, Quinn said. "We will show it to you later on, if you wish."

"The big question is, what would you like to do first?" Smiling, Maria asked. "We all celebrate each newcomer with a holiday."

"No work will be done today to give everyone a chance to get to know you." Smiling, Travis said. "I hope you don't mind crowds..."

I blushed at that. "Not really..."

After looking about, I decided to begin my tour with...
1554112111111112.title: Welcome to In-walls.

15541121111111121.content:
"Marty told me that people shrink between 18 and 38," I said to Maria, as she led me to the telegraph.

"I know," she replied. "The historians say I was the first in 100 years to shrink so young, a rare condition that only one in a billion ever get. The only thing rarer is shrinking so small. I was carried everywhere when I was mayor."

"She shrank at the age of eight, it terrified her." Calmly, Quinn said. "We took her in and found that the beeps of the telegraph calmed her. That was how she got the job."

"What of her parents.." Worried, I asked.

"Not the best of people." Wincing, Quinn whispered. "They never reported her missing. Maria had changed her surname and moved on... best not to discuss it around her."

We soon reached the telegraph, a jury-rigged device that dominated a wall. "The day begins with sending and receiving test messages," Maria said. "When those are done, we know if we're in contact with the rest of our world, or if we need to check things out."

"What do you usually use the telegraph for?"

"The scouts and gatherers are the first to detect when someone will shrink. Sometimes, the person who will shrink is only in town for a visit. So, if that happens, we alert that community. That's how we did it for Mrs. Micron."

"Mrs. Mic - oh, Marty. Micron, Minuscule, Speck: Is there a reason for that?"

"Most of us change our names, to signify the deaths of our big selves."

That gave me pause. Marty had said that she recommended I cut ties with my family. But would I ever feel so different from them that I didn't even want to share their name?
15541121111111121.title: The telegraph.

155411211111111211.content:
"You've had quite a busy day, Kylie," Quinn said, "shrinking for most of it. Perhaps it's time we gave you a place to rest your head, before we feed you."

I wasn't tired, but I figured Quinn had a point. It would be better for me to find out where I was sleeping before I was too tired to remember where it was.

Quinn led me even farther down. "The hub is where we work," she said, "and greet newcomers like yourself. Our homes are farther down."

As we descended, I heard the laughter of children. "Maria isn't quite the youngest," I said.

"She's the youngest to be employed," Quinn explained. "Because she shrank so young, and so small, we treat her as an equal. Otherwise, she would be down here with the other children."

Beneath the hustle and bustle were parents playing with children, children playing with each other, children sitting quietly by themselves. I learned that, after school, the children were encouraged to develop their own skills and interests. In this way, they could find the calling that suited them. All careers were equal among the Little People: the artist was as valued as the gatherer.

A little girl bumped into me. "Excuse me," she said, looking up at me.

"You're excused," I told her.

"I've never seen you before."

"I'm new here."

"Welcome, newcomer. I'm Daria."

"Kylie. Pleased to meet you."

She withdrew for a bit, then returned and gave me a sheet of paper and a fragment of lead from a mechanical pencil. "Welcome" was the only explanation.

Quinn led me to a one-bedroom apartment. "This is yours," she said. "If anything is wrong with the furnishings or the decorations, let us know, and we can change it for you. See you tomorrow." With that, Quinn left.

The furniture wasn't what I would have picked for myself, but I didn't care just then. It was enough for me that I fit into the chair, and onto the bed. After two days of shrinking, I had despaired of ever having things in my size again. I was in a world where I fit.

Picking up the paper and lead that Daria had given me, I decided to do some drawing. I used to draw up above, and I had been told I was good. But I doubted whether I could make a living at it. Being a TV reporter would put food on the table. Here, though, things were different.
155411211111111211.title: My Apartment

1554112111111112111.content:
I was drawing for some time before I looked up at a watch face hanging from one of the walls, it was near nine in the evening. "I guess I should start thinking about getting some sleep." Softly, I said. "My new life starts tomorrow morning."

Soft singing then reached my ears and I walked to my apartment door. In the hall was a small group of In-Wall residents singing lullabies as they slowly walked by like carolers at Christmas time. I looked down the hall and saw other residents opening their door to listen with a few joining them, adding their voices to the chorus. Among them was Daria who had given me the paper. I held up my drawing and she paused to admire it. A taller woman, whom I assumed was Daria's mother, paused as well and smiled.

"Welcome, newcomer." Softly, she said. "I am Sky... You draw very well."

"Thank you." Blushing, i said. "Is this done every night..."

Sky giggled. "Yes, we sing to our residents to help them sleep as the giant world can make very frightening noises in the night."

"Giants fear noises in the night too." Ruefully, I said.

"May I..." Blushing, Daria asked.

I nodded and handed her the paper. It was a drawing of the girl's face, which she seemed to like very much. "You can join us, if you wish." Smiling, Sky said.

"Maybe next time." Smiling back, I replied. "I'm going to need to learn my way around first, I do not wish to get lost."

Sky and Daria both giggled at that then bid me goodnight before leaving me to my rest. The bed was surprisingly comfortable and I was soon asleep to the soft sounds of the lullaby carolers. "What a strange, wondrous place." Yawning, I muttered. "I wonder what surprises await me tomorrow."

Throughout the night, I was awakened to the sounds of stomping, moaning and metal grinding. It was like a scene from a haunted house movie. Only, with it being my first night as an In-Wall, I was able to determine what the noises were. Dad walking around with his heavy steps, mom muttering in her sleep, and the water heater kicking in. "I can only imagine how frightening those sounds are to one born into this tiny world." Sleepily, I said. "Maybe there is a way to help the little ones understand the sounds better..."

With that, I was sound asleep...
1554112111111112111.title: More About In-Walls

15541121111111121111.content:
The next morning, I went up to the hub, where Quinn was making her mayoral rounds. "Good morning, Kylie," she said. "Have you thought about where your place may be?"

"I was told up above that I had artistic talent," I replied, "but I never developed it much."

"Well, let me show you to the artists' garret."

As we walked, Quinn asked, "Did you sleep well? I hope the lullaby carolers helped you: I'm sure the noises that the giants make were terrifying for you, since you're new among us."

"I'm fine," I said, "no need to worry about me. The sounds surprised me at first, but then I recognized them, and they weren't nearly as scary."

Quinn stopped in her tracks. "You know what the noises are?"

"Yes. They're a little distorted from my perspective, but I can still recognize them."

"This way," Quinn commanded, and changed both her direction and her pace.

"Where are we going?"

"To see the bards."

Apparently, the artists' garret would have to wait.

******************************


When we reached an office with people hard at work, Quinn knocked on the door frame. "This is Kylie Burke, the newcomer. She can tell us what the night sounds are."

At this news, three of the bards ran up to me. "You know the nature of the sounds? What is the rhythmic thumping noise?"

"That's my father," I replied. "He walks all over the house, making sure everything is secure, before he turns in for the night."

"The moaning?"

"Mom talks in her sleep."

"And the metallic grinding?"

"Our water heater."

"It's so simple," they said, "once you know it."

As the bards set to work, Quinn led me back out. "You have done us all a great service, Kylie," she said. "The Little People will sleep easier within a night or two."
15541121111111121111.title: The following morning.

155411211111111211111.content:
Quinn led me to a huge room compared to the rest of the community. There were doors leading in and out in many directions. Looking around I realized it was a dumbwaiter. Having never known we had one, I guessed it had been covered up in a remodel before we bought the house. "This is the community lift." Smiling, Quinn explained. "We use it to travel to all levels of In-Walls."

She nodded to a man at a jimmy-rigged control who hit a button and the lift rapidly took us up quite a ways. When it stopped, Quinn led me out one doorway into a spacious room where several people were sitting behind large canvases painting various images of life within In-Walls. "Welcome to the Artists' Garret, Kylie." Calmly, Quinn said. "Here, all artists are free to hone their talents for the benefit of the community."

"We share our work with artists from other communities." Smiling, one artist said. "With them, we offer written news coverage that ties to the paining."

"So you are reporters too..." Curious, I said.

"Fact Tellers." Kindly, another artist corrected. "In a world of giants, any opinion could spark a panic. Only the facts are allowed. If we do not know, we must say so."

I looked at what one artist was painting and smiled. "The stomping is my father making his rounds to ensure all is safe before going to bed."

The artist returned my smile. "Welcome, newcomer." Patiently, he said. "The shaking this painting refers to are earthquakes. The giants cannot detect anything below a point one on the Richter scale but we can feel it."

"Earthquakes... here?" Surprised, I asked.

Just as I said that, the room shook and I flinched seeing dust falling from the ceiling of the tiny nook in the attic. "Our scouts and gatherers have determined that the shaking is due to a water main that is close to rupturing." Serious, Quinn explained. "We are sending an alarm to Under-Streets so they can evacuate."

After a thought, I asked, "Can we contact my family, I mean the giants?"

"What will that do?" Curious, another artist asked.

"My dad knows the people who work on the underground water lines." Serious, I explained. "If I can sound the alarm to him before the line ruptures, the workers can repair it before any damage is done."

The artists stared at me for a moment before moving to a new canvas and painting as if they were possessed. "Um... was it something I said?"

"No one has ever thought to sound an alarm to the giants." Softly, Quinn said. "I do not know if it can even be done."

"If it will save lives, I have to try." Insistent, I said.

"Then I will take you to them." Calmly, Travis Minuscule said. "You can come with us when we go on our next raid."

I nodded as Quinn turned to the artists. "Send the alarm but add that we may have a plan to prevent the rupture from happening."

The artists nodded and returned to their work as I turned to Travis. "When do we leave to the world of the giants?"

"Right now." Serious, Travis replied. "Who do you want to contact?"
155411211111111211111.title: The Artists'Garret

1554112111111112111112.content:
Travis led me up the same way I had come down just the day before. Stepping out into the living room, I saw that Mom was watching game shows. "How do we get her attention away from that thing?" he asked.

"Like this," I told him. Crossing the vast expanse of living room floor, I began tugging on Mom's pant leg.

Mom ignored what I was doing for so long that I began to question the strength of my shrunken arms. Finally, with a muttered "What in the world... ?", she bent down, and looked me right in the face. "Kylie?"

"Hi, Mom," I said with a wave. "This is Travis Minuscule, a scout and gatherer for the Little People. Travis , this is my mother."

"How do you do, ma'am?"

"I'm pleased to meet you, Mr. Minuscule."

"We're here on an important mission, Mom. The Little People have detected a water main that's close to breaking. If Dad can get it fixed, he'll save a city of Little People."

"Where is the main?"

"Right over Under-Streets," Travis said.

"I'm afraid I don't know where that is. Wait here."

Mom got up and went to the kitchen. I heard her rummaging through the junk drawer. "Here it is."

She returned with a map of the city, and spread it out on the floor. "We're here," she said, pointing to one spot on the map. "Where is the main?"

Travis studied the map, following a route he'd taken who knows how many times, then pointed. "Here."

Mom looked at the spot where Travis stood, then picked up the phone and called. "Hi, Frank. Kylie came to see me. Apparently, there's a water main at 4th and Chestnut that's close to breaking." She listened. "And it wouldn't do wonders for the Little People near there. I'll tell you all about it when you come home. Bye."

After hanging up, Mom told us, "A broken water main would cause considerable property damage, and be an inconvenience to every giant who lives there. He's glad you told me."

"It was Kylie's idea," Travis said. "She said she could reach out to you and avert disaster, and she did. This after telling us what the sounds we hear coming from this place mean. I thank the fates that made her one of us."

Even Mom could see me blushing at that.

"Could we devise some way to contact each other," Mom asked, "for less time-sensitive matters? I would feel better, knowing my daughter wasn't so far away."

"For the service you have done for us today," Travis said, "I believe it could be arranged."
1554112111111112111112.title: Mom.

15541121111111121111122.content:
That night, I agreed to go with the lullaby carolers to sing for those frightened by the sounds of the giants only we were all surprised by a soft but clear song coming from the giant world. It was mom singing to Iris...

It's midnight, you're up right
You're wound up a little tight.
Scary noises you can't see
Sometimes it scares me.
That bit makes you just go crazy.
Have no fear, no doubt when mom and dad are about.
We're staying in tonight to kick out every fright
To take away your fear protect you, that's right.
We're going to keep you safe from bad dreams until the morning light...

We all fell silent listening to the lullaby as it echoed through into every room of In-Walls and silence was heard when it was over. Everyone had fallen asleep. "What a strange lullaby..." Whispering, Quinn said. "I wonder where the giant learned it."

"That giant is my mom." Smiling, I said. "She makes up songs as she goes to help Iris fall asleep. They are inspired by songs she heard when she was younger."

"Well, it seems to work here too." Softly, Quinn said. "It seems you bring blessings where ever you go."

"I'm just a person, no better than anyone else." Blushing, I said.

"Still, you are making a large impact from your first day." Smiling, Quinn said. "i would not be surprised if you are elected mayor next month."

Just then, Travis came hurrying to us, smiling. "We just received a telegraph from the Under-Streets." Out of breath, he said. "The water main is being repaired by a team of giants... Kylie's warning came just in time." He turned to me. "Fast thinking on your part, thank you."

I blushed more at that. "You're welcome."

Later on, I was taken back to my apartment, wondering what the next day would bring.
Only I did not expect to wake up to...
15541121111111121111122.title: A New Lullaby

155411211111111211111222.content:
... Travis standing at my door. "We installed a sliding drawer with access on both sides," he said. "Your mother left us this."

It was a sheet of paper folded many times, with my name written on one exposed side. "Thank you, Travis.I am in your debt."

He smiled. "Not hardly, Kylie," he said, and left.

I unfolded Mom's letter, which was big enough to prop up against the wall, and read:

Dear Kylie,

I'm so glad I asked the Little People for a way for us to stay in contact. Travis and his friends are absolute geniuses at their work. The casual observer wouldn't notice the odd feature in the baseboard, but we all see it and know what it's for.

Travis told me that some of those who shrank like you did didn't leave their families on good terms, and even changed their names, to have nothing more to do with their old selves. I am so glad that that didn't happen with us.

Frank said that the water main you told me about was maybe a day or two away from rupturing. I'm happy that your friends are safe again. If you hear of any more bad pipes, please let us know.

Travis says that he takes things that won't be missed. I told him to leave me a note asking for anything he can't find otherwise. If I don't have it, I'll gladly buy it.

Your father and your sisters have all asked me to give their love to you. I'm sure you can expect letters from them in due time.

All my love,
Mom


Leave it to a letter from Mom to start me crying. If I'd been full-sized, I might have flooded In-Walls with happy tears.
155411211111111211111222.title: A Letter from Mom

1554112111111112111112221.content:
Early the next morning, I got up and cleaned myself off before finding a nice pair of doll jeans and shirt. Once ready, I walked out and journeyed to the common hall where I found Quinn. "Blessed be, Kylie." Greeting me, she said. "I hear you received a letter from your mom."

I nodded. "The water main is being repaired as we speak and I have been asked to alert her if we hear any more bad pipes." Smiling, I said. "Also, mom asked a favor of Travis and I."

"A favor?" Curious, Quinn asked.

"She wants to know everything we need for our community." Approaching, Travis said. "If she does not have it, she promised to buy it for us."

I giggled. "So, I'm thinking today we take stock of everything we need for a while." Smiling, I said. "Stock up while the offer is still good."

Quinn smiled at that then raised her hand. "Attention all In-Walls!" Everyone fell silent and listened. "We have been given an opportunity to replenish our stockpile. Take note of everything we are low on and bring it to Kylie... our first giant ambassador!"

This stunned me. "Giant ambassador?"

"It is extremely rare that a little maintains ties with their giant family." Smiling, Travis said. "As you are still close to your family, it makes perfect sense that you be the one to contact them."

I smiled at that then raised my hand. Everyone paused to listen. "My mother has promised to replenish our stockpile." Smiling, I announced. "Do not hold back... anything you feel we need, put on the list. I will offer what funds I have left behind to cover the expenses."

Cheers rose from the crowd and they fanned out, checking every last storage room for what might be needed. Within minutes, the common hall was empty. "We will have much to celebrate tonight." Smiling, Quinn said. "Your fast thinking saved an entire community and now your family's generosity will help sustain ours for months to come if not longer."

"Just doing my part." Blushing, I said.

"You are going well above and beyond what is expected." Smiling, Travis said. He blushed slightly. "Would it be too imposing if I ask you to accompany me to the celebration tonight?"

I blushed at that but slowly smiled. "No... I would be honored."

Travis smiled, nodded, then ran off to make a list of his own. Quinn giggled seeing him cheering as he ran. "I think you just made his day." Whispering, she said.
1554112111111112111112221.title: I Write to Mom

15541121111111121111122211.content:
The list was made fairly quickly, just under a few short hours. What surprised me was that most of their current needs could be found in my old bedroom. It was everything from art supplies to water. I helped the Artists' Garret put the list together on a paper mom could read and where to leave it all. We then placed it into the communication drawer before pulling a lever. Inside the house, a small red strip appeared above the drawer, looking like a piece of nicked paint.

"Now all we can do is wait." Sighing, I said.

I spent the time waiting by drawing portraits of people at their request. Daria and her mother, Sky had apparently been telling people of my talents. I had done ten portraits in all before excited shouts and cheers were heard approaching the common hall. We all turned to see the scouts and gatherers, lead by Travis march in with a bounty of food and supplies. The first paraded trip brought small bottles of water, forty-eight of them to be exact. "This will completely replenish our fresh water wells!" Tearfully, one woman celebrated. "No more boiling water for a while!"

Travis took off the lid of one bottle with a grunt and pushed it over, sending the sparkling water into a clean metal bowl. A number of In-Walls came to it and took in the refreshing water into their mouths, cheering and crying at the same time. "There is a high metal content in the pipes." Softly, Quinn explained. "Not a real bother for giants but for us it can be lethal unless we boil the water first."

"I never really thought of it." Worried, I said. "Perhaps I can contract dad and have him put in a filter to make the water cleaner."

"That would be a big help." Smiling, Quinn said.

The next trip brought dozens of individual serving foods in a variety of brands such as cold cereal, potato chips, instant oatmeal and much more. The adults were cheering and hugging one another. Travis paused, smiling tearfully. "We normally only take enough to get by day to day." softly, he said. "What your mother had left for us to find will last for months... Thank you."

I blushed at that. "Thank my mom, she tend to mother everyone she meets."

Trip after trip, the bounty came in with everything on the list and some no one dared to ask including medical supplies. Upon seeing them, Quinn turned to Travis. "Take those directly to the infirmary." Serious, she ordered. "Dr. Will-heart will be elated to see such a large supply."

I gulped hearing that. "Are there a lot of In-Walls injured?"

"No more than in any other community." Gently, Quinn replied. "It's just that medical supplies are hard to reach..." She smiled. "This supply will be put to great use."

By the time the last trip came through, the entire community was a buzz of their good fortune. "Fellow In-Walls, tonight, we celebrate!" Smiling, Quinn announced.

Cheers rose from the crowd and a number of In-Walls toasted me with tin cups of sparkling water. I could only blush and smile...
15541121111111121111122211.title: Mom provides a bounty.

155411211111111211111222112.content:
The next day, Quinn gave me a piece of paper. "What's this?" I asked.

"My term as mayor ends tomorrow," she replied, "so it's time to elect a new mayor. Just write the name of who you nominate, sign it, and put your ballot in the collection box in the hub."

"Sign it? Don't you use secret ballots?"

"Here among the Little People, it's only considered good if you put your name on it. Secrecy implies shame."

It was difficult to argue with such reasoning, so I nominated Travis, signed my ballot, and put it in the collection box. And I gave the election no further thought for the rest of the day.

******************************


The next morning, I had just gotten dressed when I heard people gathering outside. I wondered what was going on, when they began to sing:

In harsh times when our souls are oh so weary
When we're down and our hearts are oh so heavy
We lie still and pray into the silence
Until you come to aid us in our time of need

You give us strength enough to move mountains
You give us faith to calm the stormy seas
We are one when you are our mayor
We elect you for you are who we need

How about that? I thought. Somebody here won the election. I should go see who the lucky winner is.

You can imagine my surprise, then, when I opened my door, and the crowd cheered.

While I tried to figure that out, Quinn came up to me and put a sash over my shoulder. "Congratulations, Madame Mayor," she said.

"Me? Th-there must be some mistake."

"There's no mistake, Kylie. You won almost unanimously. Yours was the only ballot not voting for you. Which makes the choice even better."

And so I was led to the mayor's home and office. "It's as I told you," Quinn said. "In your short time here, you have calmed our fears, saved our sister community, and helped us to replenish our stores. None of this has gone unnoticed."

As I sat at the desk in my new office, Quinn asked, "What would you like, Madame Mayor?"

"A piece of paper, and some lead. I have to write and tell Mom about this."
155411211111111211111222112.title: The Election

1554112111111112111112221121.content:
Dear Mom,

Believe it or not, I am writing you from the mayor's office.

No, Mom, I'm not having a meeting with Dad's boss. I have actually been elected mayor of In-Walls.

It's mostly an honorary title, as, for the most part, we govern ourselves. But I am obligated to meet with anyone who shrinks into our population, as I learned from Quinn when I left home. If I have other duties, I'll learn of them on the job. And I won't screw things up too badly, because my term is only one month.

You're probably wondering how I got elected. Well, believe it or not, you played a major part in it. Down here, we hear noises coming from the house above us, and many of us were terrified of them. But I grew up in that house before I grew down, so I knew it was just Dad checking the house, you talking in your sleep, and the water heater. That knowledge, combined with the lullaby you sang to Iris, put people at ease.

The other factors came about because I left the house on such good terms. Many of us were harmed by the big people in our lives, or were neglected as we shrank. But, because you have been so good to me, I had the idea of contacting the world of giants to fix the water main. And, because you offered to buy us what we need, and you kept your word, we have everything we need. The bottled water is especially appreciated, as impurities in the municipal water make it toxic to us.

Give the girls my love, and I'll write to you again soon.

Your loving little girl,
Kylie
1554112111111112111112221121.title: My Letter to Mom

15541121111111121111122211212.content:
As I started my first official day as mayor, I learned that Quinn was my advisor and that I would become the advisor to the next mayor. "This keeps every mayor up to date on the latest news and issues that needs to be dealt with." Calmly, Quinn said. "This way, we can better govern ourselves in the best and worst of times."

We both paused as the lights flickered then came back on just before screams and cries were heard. Concerned, Quinn and I ran to the hub where an In Wall resident was being rushed to the infirmary. "What happened?!" Worried, I demanded.

"Tommy Tiny was replacing the battery back up systems when he accidentally electrocuted himself." Wincing, Dr. Will-heart said. "He will live but his hand was badly burned in the accident."

Dr. Will-heart was an older man with bushy eyebrows and mustache that accented his gentle blue eyes. Tommy Tiny was around my age with short brown hair and brown eyes that were filled with tears from both pain and sorrow. "I had done the battery replacement a thousand times." Crying, he said. "I don't know what went wrong... I'm such a novice..."

I shushed Tommy quiet. "The difference between an expert and a novice is that an expert has made more mistakes." Calmly, I said. "Also, an expert learns from his mistakes where a novice just quits and walks away."

Tommy took my words in and smiled slightly. Taking her cue, Quinn added, "No one is faster at replacing the batteries than you, Tommy. One mistake out of a thousand is a very good record."

"Day or night, you and your teammates are on the job when the power goes out." Added another. "We never have to worry of being in the dark."

"Even with a burned hand, you finished the job." Chiming in, another said.

One after another, the residents of In-Walls spoke their praises and well wishes to Tommy Tiny as he was carried to the infirmary. "You have nothing to worry or be sorry about, brave resident." Calmly, I said. "Accidents come to us all. We learn from them and become better people from it."

Once Tommy was in the infirmary, Quinn smiled at me. "You did well on your first day as mayor." Kindly, she said. "We have long believed that good and evil exists in each one of us and that giving in to one's bad nature is a cry for help." She motioned to the people around us. "So we affirm the good nature of the wrongdoer, in hopes he or she will correct their behavior before it gets serious. This is called ubuntu."

I nodded at that then turned to Maria Speck. "Any news from the telegraph?"

Maria nodded. "The people of Under-Streets are grateful for the quick action to repair the water main." Smiling, she replied. "They also gave word of a newcomer to their community, a homeless teenager named Micheal Fawn..."

A tear of joy fell from my eye as I knew the homeless boy. My family had offered to take him in many times but he refused to be a burden to anyone. "He is homeless no longer; he is now a member of the Under-Streets community." Happy, I said. "Send word that we also extend our welcomes to the newcomer."

Maria smiled and hurried off to send the message. I then turned to Travis who brought news of...
15541121111111121111122211212.title: Ubuntu

155411211111111211111222112122.content:
"This is a noteworthy week," Travis said. "Another will be shrinking within a few days."

I turned to Quinn. "Is this unusual?"

"We've gone months with the only new citizens being born here," she replied, "but three people shrinking in a week is a rare occurrence."

I turned back to Travis. "So, do we know anything about this coming newcomer?"

"Her name is Jillian Warner."

The blood drained from my face.

"Are you alright, Madame Mayor?" Quinn asked.

"Jillian... Warner? You're sure?"

"Did you know her?"

"She was my best friend five feet ago. Travis, could we... tell her?"

"Tell her? You mean, tell her that she's going to shrink? We... we've never tried it before."

"Madame Mayor," Quinn said, "we prefer to keep our existence a secret."

"Jillian already knows. She was with my family when I said goodbye. Just slip into her room, as you were planning to do later, and tell her before it happens."

"But what if she runs away?"

I shook my head. "The farthest she'll run is to my house. She'll want to be surrounded by people who love her, just as I was."

Travis shrugged. "You've guided us well since you came to us. We will give it a try."
155411211111111211111222112122.title: A newcomer to In-Walls.

1554112111111112111112221121221.content:
Just as Travis agreed to my plan, we all heard wailing from the house. Everyone in the hub cringed and turned to me. "It sounds as though something is wrong within the giant household, madame mayor." Softly, Quinn said.

I knotted my jaws in decision and turned to Travis. "We need to investigate." Firmly, I ordered. "Gather a small party and we will see what the issue is." I sighed. "If luck is with us, it is nothing more than Iris having a bad dream."

Travis nodded and gathered two of his fellow scouts and gatherers who led me into the house through an abandoned mouse hole. There, we found Jillian crying and wailing in the arms of mom and dad who were doing their best to comfort her. This concerned me greatly and I was tempted to run out to speak to her but there would be no way for me to get their attention safely.

"They're gone!" Crying, Jillian wailed. "Mom... dad in a car crash! I- I don't have anyone left... I'm so scared!"

"We will take care of you." Gently, mom said. "My husband will call our attorney and we'll get the paperwork rolling."

I was crying at this point but I also knew that it was more important now than ever to get their attention. I looked about and found that the family was playing Karaoke before Jillian came running to the house and to my fortune, the microphone was lying on the floor. I turned to Travis. "Can we get to the mic without getting trampled?"

Travis nodded. "There is an access port just behind the speaker we use as a shortcut to the kitchen."

Travis led me back through the winding halls to the access port where the microphone was in sight. I hurried up to it and covered my ears as I spoke into it. "Um... mom... this is Kylie."

Mom and dad turned to the Karaoke machine and spotted me by the microphone. "Hey, honey." Tearfully, mom said. "Is something wrong?"

"Well, yes and no." Wincing, I said into the mic. "We have strong evidence that Jillian is about to shrink just as I did."

Jillian gasped. "Are you certain...." Softly, she demanded.

"We have a sixth sense about such things." Stepping up to the mic, Travis said. "We weep for your family, Miss Warner."

"Thank you..." Crying, Jillian said. "Do- Do you know when this is going to happen?"

"You will be our height within a few hours." To my surprise, Travis said. "Strong emotions such as sadness or anguish greatly speed up the process."

"Is there anything I need to do before I..." Wincing, Jillian asked.

"Cover your tracks." After a thought, I said. "Just as the world thinks I have passed away, so must the world think of you."

Jillian nodded, tears flowing like rivers as dad walked off to contact his attorney. By the time he got off the telephone, Travis and I along with the two scout and gatherers were leading a frightened and uncertain Jillian to the hub..."
1554112111111112111112221121221.title: Tragic transition.

1554112111111112111112221121222.content:
An hour later, Travis returned. "I told her first that you were our mayor," he said. "That put her in a pleasant frame of mind, which I think cushioned the blow when I told her why you sent me."

"Good choice, Travis," I said. "Did she say anything?"

"She said that she had been hoping to see you again, but that perhaps she should have been more specific about the preferred circumstances."

"Yeah, that sounds like Jillian. What's the usual course of action from this point? I'm sure my memories don't present the full picture."

"We place a watch over her," Quinn replied, "to make sure that she is well."

I nodded. "If you're waiting for my permission to proceed, you have it."

"Already done, Madame Mayor," Travis assured me. "We will have eyes on her until she has arrived in In-Walls."

Just then, someone ran in and whispered something to Quinn. She nodded, and the person left the way she came.

"Anything I need to know about?" I asked.

"Perhaps, in this instance," she replied. "Jillian and her parents have had words. Apparently, they wanted her to seek medical attention, in an effort to prevent or halt her shrinking."

"And she didn't want attention, medical or otherwise."

Quinn nodded.

"I was the same way, though my parents were more understanding."

"What now, Madame Mayor?"

"As I said before, she's likely to go up above us to my parents' house. That will likely be where we'll find her, when the time comes."

******************************


Some time later, as I was settling in at the mayor's quarters, Quinn came to see me. "As you suspected," she said, "Jillian is with the giants above us. They have welcomed her, and she is relatively comfortable."

"Relatively?"

Quinn nodded. "She has begun to shrink."
1554112111111112111112221121222.title: Watch

15541121111111121111122211212221.content:
The next morning, as Quinn reminded me, I proclaimed a holiday from work in In-Walls, so that we could all welcome Jillian when she joined us.

To my surprise, it wasn't long into the day before the city filled with cries of "Newcomer!" and " Welcome!"

I cast an inquiring glance at Quinn. "If she was worked up over the argument with her parents," she explained, "she may have shrunk faster."

When we saw her, another reason for her early arrival became clear: She had elected to join us while she was still 8 inches tall.

As I drew closer, I understood what Travis had said, as I was able to sense that Jillian wasn't done shrinking yet. "Welcome, newcomer, to In-Walls," I said. "I am Kylie Burke, this month's mayor."

"You didn't have to introduce yourself to me, Kylie," she said, hugging me. "God, it feels good to hug you again."

"Actually , I do have to introduce myself. It's part of the tradition. You'll find out, I'm sure, when it's your turn to be mayor."

"That's okay. I never did have a thing for politics."

"No politics involved. Everyone here gets to be mayor. Quinn, here, was mayor when I came down. But I'm getting ahead of myself. I suggest that you introduce yourself, so our people know what to call you after today."

She raised her hand. "Jillian Warner."

"How are things with your family?" I asked. "I heard there was a disagreement."

"We patched things up before I came down here," she said. "I know they wanted to help me, but this is something that couldn't be helped. Todd was with me at the end. I think he might ask if he can move in with your family, so he can be near both of us."

I shook my head. "He should really go looking for a girl his size."

"He will, Kylie, give him time. Think of it as a breakup: if he found someone else right away, how would you feel?"

"Good point. Ah, here comes one of our more popular citizens. Jillian Warner, this is Maria Speck, our telegrapher."

"Pleased to meet you," Jillian said. "Will I be getting as small as you?"

"Doubtful," Maria replied. "I'm something of a special case. I shrank when I was 8."

"Today is a holiday," I told Jillian, "so everyone in In-Walls can get to know you, and vice versa. When I'm not mayor, I am one of the artists. Let's show you around, so that you know this city as your own."
15541121111111121111122211212221.title: Jillian Warner, Newcomer

155411211111111211111222112122211.content:
"It was surreal." In a dreamy voice, Jillian said. "Mr and Mrs Burke held a little ceremony to send me off by softly playing We'll meet again by Vera Lynn. Iris dropped tiny rose petals to send me off and Todd sent me off with a message..."

"What kind of message?" Smiling, I asked.

Jillian smiled. "If anyone hurts you or me to let him know."

I giggled. "That's Todd for you." Bemused, I said.

"He will have to get in line." Grinning, Travis said.

Jillian and I giggled at that and the tour began. "The telegraph allows us to communicate with other communities and beyond." Calmly, I explained. "We just recently saved the community of Under-Streets from a terrible flood due to an old water main that was about to burst."

"I remember that." Smiling, Jillian said. "My dad couldn't figure out how Mr. Burke knew it was about to break." She turned serious. "He has sworn to keep the communities a carefully guarded secret... my dad's word is his bond."

I nodded at that. "We appreciate that." Calmly, I said. "We also have a post office where we can send letters to my mom. We can use it to send letters to your family as well, if you wish."

"I'd like that." smiling, Jillian said.

The tour ended with a stop at the infirmary. "Why are we here?" Curious, Jillian asked.

"To check in on a citizen who was hurt." Calmly, I said. "Part of my duties is to see to everyone's well being."

We entered to find Dr Will-heart working on removing the bandages on Tommy Tiny's hand. "Ah, madame mayor." Nodding, Will-heart said. "What brings you to me?"

"Giving our latest newcomer, Jillian Warner a tour and to check in on Tommy Tiny." Calmly, I replied. "How are you holding up?"

The bandages came off revealing Tommy's hand was no worse for the experience. "I'm as good as new." Smiling, he said. He turned to Jillian. "Welcome, newcomer."

"Yes, welcome, newcomer." Smiling, Will-heart said. "If you have any medical issues, please do not hesitate to seek me out."

Jillian nodded at that and I escorted her to her apartment. "This is where you will be living from here on in." Smiling, I said. "If there is anything you would like changed to better suit you, just let us know."

"Thank you, Kylie." Smiling, Jillian said. "I- I don't know what I would do if I were all alone in this."

"We have groups who have gone through this alone." Calmly, I said. "If you feel the need to talk about it, they will come to you."

I left Jillian to settle in and returned to my office where I found Travis waiting for me with a sense of uncertainly about him. "Is something wrong?" Concerned, I asked.

"There is something I wish to discuss with you, madame mayor... Kylie." In a shy voice, Travis said.

I sighed. "What happened...?"

Travis blushed more. "It's not what happened but what I hope will happen." Cryptically, he said. He produced a wolffia flower. "Will you accompany me on a first date?"

I blushed at that. Travis and I have become great friends in the past few weeks but I never expected him, anyone to try to take it to the next level. I turned to him, taken aback, not sure how to respond. Finally, I smiled and replied...
155411211111111211111222112122211.title: Showing Jillian Around

1554112111111112111112221121222111.content:
"I'm sorry, Travis," I said, "I'm afraid it's just too soon. Not so long ago, I had a steady boyfriend, and I had no idea you even existed. I just had a discussion about waiting a suitable time before looking for someone else." I smiled. "Let's take some time to get to know each other, before we start talking about dating."

Travis nodded. "If you say so, Madame Mayor."

"That's another reason: For the next 29 days, I'm your boss. Among the giants, such relationships don't generally go well. I would hate to have to leave In-Walls, or to lose our best scout and gatherer, if it happened to us."

Travis smiled. "At least I know that nobody else will lay claim to your heart in the time ahead."

"Just a little patience. That's all I ask."

"May I ask for a token, to hold out hope?"

"I believe I can grant that request." I stepped up to him and kissed him. "Will that be suitable?"

"Very much so, Madame Mayor." With that, he left, one hand touching his lips.

I know that last part, because his arm was bent the same way mine was, as I touched my lips.
1554112111111112111112221121222111.title: It's too soon.

15541121111111121111122211212221111.content:
The next day, two letters came. One for me from Sara and one for Jillian from her parents and brother. I did not know what to expect as I had not heard from my sisters since I became an In-Walls citizen...

Kylie,

You might want to know that strange car you mentioned a few weeks ago was parked outside again. Iris told me that she saw some people pointing strange devices at the ground as if they were looking for treasure on the beach. It might be nothing but it might also be something too. We will keep an eye on them and keep you informed.

Love always, Sara and Iris.

With the letter was a simple but strange symbol that looked like an flower made from infinity signs. "Who could know about us?" Worried, I muttered.

I decided to bring it to Quinn's attention who, upon reading the letter, let out a worried sigh. "It's Lotus." Softly, she said. "They are a little known research group obsessed with the strange and unusual."

"Do they know about us?" Worried, I asked.

Quinn shook her head. "Fortunately, no." More calmly, she replied. "I believe they are more interested in the strange disappearances in this area over the passed week." She shook her head. "There were stories circulating last year about giants shrinking due to a mysterious comet but they are just that, stories."

"Which is how you learned of them." Guessing correctly, I said.

Quinn nodded. "Exactly."

I knotted my jaws in decision. "We will need to alert the other communities to exercise extreme caution when out on their raids until we are certain they have left the area."

"A wise decision, madame mayor." Calmly, Quinn said. "We will send word."

Later on, I decided to pay Jillian a visit at her apartment to find her looking worried. "What's wrong?" Concerned, I asked.

"Some strange people came to our door, asking about my disappearance." Frowning, Jillian said. "Dad had already sent word that I had passed away and sent them to curb with a very convincing act but..."

"It's the fact strange people asked." Sighing, I said. Jillian nodded. I explained who they were then added, "Fortunately, they do not know of us, to my knowledge. We are sending word to be extra cautious until they leave the area."

"I hope its soon." Wincing, Jillian said.

"Me too." Nodding, I agreed.
15541121111111121111122211212221111.title: Letters from Home

155411211111111211111222112122211111.content:
I was just stepping out of Jillian's apartment when Maria showed up. "Hi, Madame Mayor," she said. "I have a message for you."

"And you knew to look for me here?" I marveled. "You're a regular Radar O'Reilly, aren't you?"

"Who?"

"Skip it. What's the message?"

"I asked around about any information anyone had about Lotus, and I found some people who used to work with them. They said that Lotus isn't a bunch of sadists or crazies; they're dedicated scientists, interested in advancing human knowledge and the human condition. You know, so we don't have to worry about being dissected, or them using us to try to shrink the world."

"That may be so, Maria, but I won't have my people put themselves in danger. I'll modify my earlier directive to say that no hostile action should be taken, but, again, they should be avoided if it's at all possible. Thanks for the message. You went above and beyond."

With that taken care of, I went about my mayoral duties, which mainly consisted of talking to the people of In-Walls. I felt it was only fair, since they had voted for me. I got to hold a baby, and I had a talk with a very pregnant woman.

My walk took me to the edge of In-Walls, where I saw what I assumed was a route to one of the other communities of Little People. With the distances involved, it was certainly a good thing we had a working telegraph system. Still, I was sure that a way to get there physically would come in handy.

That was when I saw it: a car, about our size. It was covered with a thick layer of dust. I recognized it as a plaything I had discarded years ago, an old radio controlled car that I couldn't get to work right. How did it get down here?
155411211111111211111222112122211111.title: Researching Lotus.

1554112111111112111112221121222111111.content:
When I returned to my office, Quinn was there. "How are things with Jillian?" she asked.

"Lotus had words with her family," I said with a sigh. "Her dad put them off the track. Still, they were curious about her. Maria went to see me. She says Lotus won't mean any harm. But then, Marty's first husband didn't mean her any harm, did he?"

"True. Anything else of interest?"

"I found an old RC car I used to own. How did it get down here?"

"One piece at a time. Larry Particle, one of our scouts and gatherers, fixed it up so that one of us could drive to Under-Streets. Then, a couple of years ago, it quit working, which is why we don't use it anymore."

"Larry couldn't fix it again?"

She bowed her head. "He ran into a cat."

"Oh. I'm sorry."

"You couldn't have known."

"Say, I just thought of something: Sara is something of an amateur gearhead. Perhaps I could write to her, she could send me some pointers, and we could fix the car. Then, we could teach other citizens how to do it, so keeping it working won't be up to one person."

"A splendid idea, Madame Mayor."

I grabbed a sheet of paper, and began to write.
1554112111111112111112221121222111111.title: The Car

15541121111111121111122211212221111111.content:
A few hours after sending a letter to Sara, I got a response and a rather large package that turned out to be a rechargeable battery pack for the RC car. Sara left instructions on how to change the battery out safely in her letter.

Kylie, the RC car you mentioned was a recalled model which had a battery pack that never held a good charge. The company made it that way to sell more but it backfired as it worked with pretty much any RC car battery pack on the market. This pack will keep the car moving for a long time to come and it is already fully charged. Included is a list of instructions I hope will help.

All our love,

Sara.

I sent word to Tommy Tiny who helped me change out the battery and safely dispose of the old one before checking all of the other controls. "Everything looks ready." Smiling, I said. "Who is going to give it a test run?"

"I'll test her." Calmly, Travis said. "There are two seats... want to visit Under-Streets?"

I turned to Quinn who nodded. "We will all visit Under-Streets eventually." Smiling, she said. "You might as well do it now."

I nodded in return and turned to Travis. "Let's get going then."

Within minutes, Travis was driving the modified RC car through what seemed to be an impossible twisting maze of tunnels. I must admit, I was a bit frightened but Travis was surprisingly calm. "We use cat urine in these tunnels to keep the various rodents away from the ones we use." Serious, he said. "Gathering it, however is a dangerous task left only to those willing to volunteer."

I nodded though I was still worried as Travis brought with him a homemade crossbow with small modified needles for arrows. "Even in their world, weapons seem to be a dark necessity..."

Within minutes, we had arrived at Under-Streets. Only I was not prepared for what I found there... I was inside what looked like an old subway station only in my size! Everything looked recreated from pictures I had seen online. Seeing my reaction, Travis chuckled. "The people of this community dug out and built this city with their bare hands." With a hint of pride, he said. "Much like we did with In-Walls."

"We like it." Approaching us, a young woman said. "I am Tonya Freckle, this month's mayor of Under-Streets."

"Kylie Burke." Smiling, I said. "I am this month's mayor of In-Walls."

Tonya nodded. "Welcome. Is this an official visit or a social call."

"A little of both." Calmly, I replied. "We have news about Lotus, the strange giants poking around on the surface."

Before Tonya could respond, we were all greeted by a chorus of "Newcomer!" and "Welcome!"

I giggled and prepared myself for another welcoming party.
15541121111111121111122211212221111111.title: Sara Comes Through

155411211111111211111222112122211111111.content:
"Strictly speaking," I told the people of Under-Streets, "we are not newcomers. We are visitors from In-Walls. This is Travis Minuscule, and I am this month's mayor of In-Walls, Kylie Burke."

And, just like that, the welcoming cries of "Newcomer!" were replaced by shouts of "Hooray!" as the townsfolk lifted me onto their shoulders.

"Is this how we usually welcome visitors?" I asked.

"They know it was your idea to send the giants to repair the water main," Tonya explained. "You saved our city, and they're rewarding you as best we can."

"Alright, then, if you insist," I said. "Please take us to the mayor's office."

******************************


"So, then," Tonya said, "what can you tell me about Lotus?"

"From what Maria, our telegrapher, has gathered, their motives are pure. They want to learn, and to help people. They don't mean us any harm."

"Lord deliver me from giants who mean no harm."

"In that spirit, I've directed my people not to initiate hostilities, but to avoid them as long as possible. Hopefully, they'll lose interest and go away again."

"Let's hope so. I shudder to think of what might happen to one of us in their clutches."

15541121112.content:
I slept uneasily that night, fearful of what I would find in the morning. I looked up at the clock and found it was midnight. I also found that I was now the size of of my favorite teddy bear, a mere two feet tall. Tears overflowed my eyes and I began to sob silently. I do not know how long I was crying before a strange voice reached me... "Please don't cry, it will be alright..."

I jumped and looked around until the voice came again. "Up here."

Fearful, I looked up and was surprised to find a tiny girl standing no taller than my alarm clock, about six inches. "Who- What are you?!"

The girl giggled. "My name is Tina Bitty." Smiling, she replied. "Your great aunt Beth says to say hello."

"My great aunt..." Confused, I asked. "She disappear..." I stopped, Tina smiling more as I made the connection. "She shrank too..."

Tina nodded. "It skips a generation or two but yes, it runs in your family." Calmly, she said. "Your great aunt asked me to check up on you."

"How did she know?" Wincing, I demanded.

"She has been watching over you and your family for years." Serious, Tina replied. "The shrinking hits between the eighteenth and thirty eighth year."

"Lucky me to get it right on my eighteenth birthday." Pouting, I said.

"There is another celebration waiting for you at the mansion." Calmly, Tina said.

"The mansion?" Worried, I asked.

"It will soon be too dangerous for you to live with your family." Serious, Tina replied. "Your great aunt Beth will come for you when the time comes."

With that said, Tina ran towards the wall where she crossed what looked like a bridge made of a ruler into a hole in the wall. The ruler was then pulled back and the tiny section of wall was closed.

I did not know what to think at that point... Did I dream that or did it really happen?

I wanted to ponder over it more only exhaustion took over and I was fast asleep in the next breath.

info.brief_description: I am slowly changing into a monster! What can I do!?
info.description:
First, some clarity here... All monsters are welcome. Vampires, werewolves, mummies, witches, warlocks, mad scientists, zombies...Mythological monsters such as Medusa, Hydra, Centaur... Giant monsters such as King Kong, Godzilla, Rodan... the only limit is your imagination. The goal of the story is how the character reacts and copes with becoming a Monster Child.

The Rules are simple....

1. Keep this at Rated PG13.

2. Do not kill the main character.

3. All chapters are to be done in first person. (Me, I, I'm, etc.)

4. The main character must be a teenager or younger! Remember the title. Keep the main character young.

5. Make a story out of the change! The character you choose will be slowly transforming into a monster of mythology or other legends. Try to describe the transformation, what senses your character develops, what tastes for food they experience, etc. How people will react to the changes, if they notice at all, or the character hides it.

6. Know the monster you are creating! Extreme examples: werewolves do not have wings and vampires do not get a tan on the beach. Let's try to keep the stories real. The only exception to this rule is if you can come up with a reason for the oddity, such as a magical ring that protects the vampire from the sun.

7. Make your monster gentle! He or she started as a regular teenager. If you can come up with something extreme that throws him or her over the edge, I will allow it.

8. Other characters are welcome. Add in monsters, humans, half humans... Go for it! Just do not break any of the above rules.

9. If you have any questions, E-mail me.

10. Have fun...
